title: trikala greece first smart city dont need to know a politician to get something done
story: Trikala, in Greeceâ€™s agricultural heartland, is an unlikely candidate for a leading smart city â€“ but innovations have improved lives despite the financial crisisâ€œIn the past, residents had to call the vice mayor just to change a broken street lamp,â€ says Sonia Sofou, a police officer turned civil servant. â€œNow you donâ€™t need to know a politician to get something done.â€The 37-year-old is hard at work in the control room of Trikala, Greeceâ€™s first smart city. On the wall, nine screens display colourful maps and graphs monitoring the availability of parking spaces, the status of traffic lights and water pipes, the location of rubbish trucks and the town hallâ€™s monthly budget.Sofou answers the phone, logging reports of uncollected rubbish and fallen tree branches into the small cityâ€™s e-complaint system. As she works, the information shows up on one of the screens above her.Smart cities â€“ usually defined as those that use technology to improve services, increase transparency and become more efficient â€“ are proliferating around the world. Pioneered in Europe, they can now be found everywhere from India to Korea. With more than two-thirds of the worldâ€™s population expected to live in cities by 2050, finding ways to make cities work better for the people who live in them has become a priority. Major companies such as Intel, Cisco Systems and IBM are involved in researching new applications in this growing field.Set among green fields in the agricultural heartland of Greece, the historic city of Trikala â€“ population 82,000 â€“ was not an obvious candidate for the nationâ€™s first smart city.The country was in the grips of a financial crisis and the municipality was â‚¬45m (Â£40m) in debt when Dimitris Papastergiou became mayor in 2014. There was zero budget for his grand, tech-savvy plans.But through collaborations with partners including the European commission, which funded a driverless bus pilot, and companies such as Greeceâ€™s Sieben and Parkguru, Trikala has earned a reputation for innovation that dates back to 2004 when Greeceâ€™s Ministry of Economics named it the nationâ€™s first digital city. It was later shortlisted as one of the top 21 smart cities in the world. By participating in EU-funded projects and offering up a test site for local tech companies, the city has cut its debt by â‚¬20m.Trikala is also the only place in Greece to have supplied Lego and Raspberry Pi robotics kits to all its 120 public schools, a move paid for by e-Trikala, a company created in 2008 to fund local innovation that is majority-owned by the municipality.Over in the echoing corridors of the 7th High School of Trikala, ICT teacher Vassilios Spachos shows off his robotics lab â€“ the first of its size in a Greek public school when it opened in 2015 with a grant from the Stavros Niarchos Foundation and support from the municipality. Standing around tables of hand-built creations that can escape mazes, climb stairs and analyse water quality, he explains why such opportunities are so important for Trikalaâ€™s youth.Tech aside, Trikala was also the first city to actually enforce the 2008 national smoking ban in all enclosed public spaces by working with local business owners and using social media to extoll the benefits of ditching cigarettes â€“ although local bars and restaurants initially grumbled about the crackdown.There were also complaints about the removal of 80 parking spaces to make room for driverless bus lanes, especially when the municipality converted them to permanent bike paths after the pilot ended. Papastergiou recalls being accused by one city council opponent of making life difficult for people with cars, something he takes as a compliment.Unsurprisingly, some among the older generation scorn the hi-tech initiatives as pointless. â€œThere are a few who think, we donâ€™t need that,â€ says 79-year-old retiree George Kiriakoulis, who took a ride on the driverless bus once out of curiosity. â€œBut mostly my friends are positive on these new things.â€This shift in attitudes is one of Trikalaâ€™s biggest achievements, says Pantoleon Skayannis, a professor specialising in innovation at the University of Thessalyâ€™s department of planning and regional development.It â€œmight not be Nasa technologyâ€, he says, â€œbut they create an environment in which citizens are gradually immersed and get used to IT.â€The city has big plans for the future. Trikala wants to join the EUâ€™s Activage programme, which tests smart houses that monitor elderly residentsâ€™ health by detecting movement and food consumption. Trikala also wants to further develop a farming project which uses technology to grow ancient medicinal plants for the pharmaceutical industry.For ICT teacher Spachos, creating smarter cities is the key to tackling this problem. â€œTech is the only sector that gives young people the tools to succeed in life nowadays, just look at the wealthy people in the world,â€ he says, shaking his head.â€œIf our country could follow the example of this municipality, maybe we could get out of this crisis.â€Follow  Cities on Twitter, Facebook and Instagram to join the discussion, and explore our archive here

title: britain shared spaces pubs youth clubs libraries austerity
story: Austerity and technology have combined to close pubs, youth clubs and libraries up and down the countryIn our towns, villages and suburbs, they are now such a common sight as to be mundane: boarded-up pubs, awaiting conversion to some new use or forlornly falling into dereliction. The&nbspcurrent rate of closure is put at 18 a week. In rural areas, shuttered hostelries represent something particularly tragic: with churches reduced to silent visitor attractions and shops&nbsplong since gone, they embody the demise of precious local assets in places where maintaining community life is an ongoing struggle.Blame for the demise of pubs tends to focus on the 2007 smoking ban, impossible business rates and beer duty, the ocean of cheap alcohol sold by the big supermarkets, and younger peopleâ€™s dwindling interest in booze and its associated rituals. Even if it ignores the ways in which many pubs have changed, the enduring idea that they are essentially male environments must also be part of any explanation. But there is also a clear sense of something every bit as fundamental: the decline of shared spaces, and the way we seem to be&nbspsplintering into ever-smaller social niches. Many local&nbspbusinesses and institutions that depend on attracting a wide range of people are fading away. Worse still, the local and national politicians who might&nbspintervene often seem either not to care or to be&nbspmaking&nbspa bad situation even worse.If our era has a pre-eminent gathering space, in both its chain and independent forms, it is&nbspsurely the modern cafe â€“ where most people seem to&nbspbe&nbsphunched over their laptops, transfixed by their phones, or huddled with friends and oblivious to everyone else. This is the opposite of the places where the best kind of chaotic, unexpected experiences can happen and you might end up falling into conversations with complete strangers.As well as the stripping-back of some of the most essential public services, one of the key effects of 10&nbspyears of austerity has been the crushing of countless other shared spaces: drop-in centres, libraries, Sure Starts. Perhaps the most overlooked casualties have been the hundreds of youth centres and clubs that have closed since 2010. More than 600 such facilities in Britain have shut over the last six years, with the loss of 139,000 youth places and 3,650 staff. In our major cities, anxiety about this organised neglect is focused on gangs and knife crime. In quieter parts of the country peopleâ€™s worries are more&nbspbasic â€“ as in Gywnedd, north Wales, where recent plans to close all 39 of the countyâ€™s youth clubs were greeted with the unanswerable argument that â€œyoung people will have nowhere but the streets to socialise with each other in the eveningsâ€.In the Cheshire suburb where I grew up, I depended on such places, which offered the same social mixture as our local comprehensive school only without maths, history and geography getting in the way. Bands were formed relationships came and went naifs like me learned vital life-skills such as how to play pool properly and the correct use of swear words. Naturally enough, there were fights, acts of vandalism, illicit drunkenness and more, but the saint-like youth workers â€“ at the club I&nbspwent to most often, they were from the local Methodist church â€“ knew what they were doing was important, and bravely persevered. This was where I found out not just who I was, but that people were often completely unlike&nbspwhatever outward stereotype they presented.On one hand cuts on the other, deep cultural changes that are pushing us even further apart. Among some middle-class people there has long been a cringe about anything that smacks of cultural universalism, but this prejudice now seems to be defining an ever-greater swath of our culture. Most obviously, the 20th-century model of egalitarian consumerism (summed up by what Andy Warhol said about Americaâ€™s greatest export: â€œA Coke is a Coke and no amount of money can get you a better Coke than the one the bum on the corner is drinkingâ€) is now something to be sneered at rather than aspired to, not least when it comes to the places where we eat and drink. From Wetherspoons to McDonaldâ€™s, places that emphasise affordability and an appeal that runs across income groups and generations are viewed more snobbishly than ever. Better, it seems, to be an habituÃ© of a bespoke cafe bar with the correct selection of craft beer, halloumi and chips for the kids. The&nbspdownside of hipster culture, perhaps, is that it combines its love of quality with elitism and exclusion.All this affects the most basic facet of how we interact with others: our mating rituals. If these things used to at least partly happen in the random cacophony of the pub and club, the new world is surely symbolised by internet dating. In many ways, this is a good thing. It has been massively liberating for the LGBTQ community, and research suggests it also increases the likelihood of people pairing beyond their own ethnic group. But there are also downsides, typified by the kind of dating sites whose proposition is so sniffy as to be almost self-parodic (witness Ivory Towers, an online service that claims to have ensured â€œthousands of postgrads from Oxbridge and beyond have found love, friendship and marriageâ€). It is not hard to see where this kind of social filtering leads. As a recent article in the Economist put it: â€œAssortative mating, the process whereby people with similar education levels and incomes pair up, already shoulders some of the blame for income inequality. Online dating may make the effect more pronounced: education levels are displayed prominently on dating profiles in a way they would never be offline.â€This much we know: with social mobility having stalled and deep class and regional inequalities intensifying a sense of a country hopelessly ided, we need to think not just about the economic forces that have pushed everything in that direction, but the way the same separation plays out every&nbspminute of our ordinary lives. In the Britain of 2018, one question for the kind of people who have probably never set foot in their local boozer has become a cliche: do you know anyone who voted leave? Soon enough, it may be superseded by an even more alarming one: do you know anyone who isnâ€™t exactly like you?

title: genocide rohingya international community myanmar rwanda
story: The time for talk is over. The international community has to act, or it could fail in Myanmar just as it failed in RwandaA UN report has accused the Myanmar military of genocide. The report is being taken, by some at least, as a call to action, with the UKâ€™s foreign secretary, Jeremy Hunt, immediately promising to visit the country â€œto seek answers at the earliest opportunityâ€.The UN passed the genocide convention, which defines genocide in legal terms, in December 1948. It sets out genocide as a series of actions â€“ ranging from killing to imposing measures to prevent births â€“ committed with the intent to destroy, in whole or in part, a national, ethnic, racial or religious group.The question of whether what has been happening to the Rohingya in Myanmar can be defined as genocide is not a new one. It started well before the forced expulsions of a year ago. In fact, the accusation of genocide being perpetrated in Myanmar â€“ against various groups â€“ has been raised repeatedly over the last two decades. It is essential that today the attempt to define whether genocide has been perpetrated does not continue to serve as a distraction to addressing the situation itself.In 2005, a report by Guy Horton labelled the violent military actions against Karen people in Myanmar as genocide. His approach was to take the definition of the crime of genocide and break it down into component parts. He then identified specific acts on the ground that could be compared with each part, and argued that, when put together, the case of genocide was made.It was a form of inverse logic. Horton believed that inidual incidents â€“ however disparate geographically and over time â€“ when considered as a piece provided a sufficient basis to argue the overall intent of the elimination of a people, which underpins the definition of the crime of genocide.This approach generated much discussion. There were some who thought the methodology too mechanistic, and that it did not work in establishing the intent that is so important to the definition of genocide. Others thought the approach very credible. Which side various groups took was not unrelated to their own positioning: the categorisation of genocide was in part used to further demonise the regime committing the act â€“ and to justify the application of crippling economic sanctions.Almost 10 years later, a case was once again made that genocide was being committed in Myanmar. In early 2016, Al-Jazeera produced a hard-hitting documentary in which the International Human Rights Clinic at Yale University used a similar deconstructionreconstruction methodology to argue acts of genocide against the Rohingya. And while international bodies debated whether to call it such, crimes against humanity and war crimes continued to be perpetrated. No tangible action was taken, and more than two-thirds of the population were forced to flee to Bangladesh.In the wake of the second world war, genocide has become the pinnacle of absolute crimes, and has surpassed, in terms of gravity, war crimes and crimes against humanity. But is this right? This debate is ongoing â€“ but such discussions must not detract from the fact that all three must be condemned and addressed with equal determination and force. Debating which category atrocities fall into without taking any action just anaesthetises the international community to the need to address any of them.True, in the case of genocide, the commitment was made by the UN general assembly for immediate action 70 years ago. But how relevant was such a bold resolution, when in practice it was disavowed in the course of the Rwanda genocide in 1994? More than 800,000 people were slaughtered in three months, while the international community â€“ fearing the obligation to intervene â€“ stood by and postponed the acknowledgement of the nature of the horrors until it no longer mattered.The terrible crimes against the Rohingya are clearly crimes against humanity, and possibly war crimes. I fear that pursuing the debate about whether or not they constitute genocide for too long could become a distraction that results in delaying further the building of collective international will to take necessary action. Defining an act as genocide involves legal substantiations that are often difficult to make or satisfy. All the more so in this case, where the United Nations Commission of Experts were never permitted to enter Myanmar. This fact alone may end up polarising members of the international community (none more so than those on the security council) and ultimately justifying inaction. One needs to look no further than the myriad international interests that have come into play in an attempt to resolve the Syrian conflict to appreciate the risk.We could possibly reach an answer to the question of whether genocide is being committed. But at what cost? Will naming it so then risk fracturing international commitment to act and undermine a more robust response? War crimes and crimes against humanity are sufficiently grave offences to justify international action. However we refer to them, immense crimes have been and are being committed in Myanmar. It is time for the world to stop debating how to categorise them and focus on finding the necessary resolve to act.â€¢ Charles Petrie is a former assistant secretary general of the UN, and was the UN deputy humanitarian coordinator in Rwanda during the 1994 genocide

title: marooned ship brexiteers phoney claims
story: I last visited the ship two years ago, already long marooned at its berth. Returning last week, Great Yarmouth had become a near-prison for its&nbspIndian captain and crew, waiting for their back pay that never came. The Malaviya Twenty is a silent symbol of the sinking British shipping industry. Why was an Indian ship employed to ply to and from British ports, servicing the British oil industry and British wind farms? Because a foreign-registered ship could pay its crew a third of a British crewâ€™s wages or less: despite government guidance, the UK minimum wage isnâ€™t currently enforceable. With the oil industry downturn, the Malaviyaâ€™s owners stopped paying the crew and there the ship stayed, arrested by maritime authorities. But&nbspsoon the crew will be free.Captain Rastogi and his last four crew finally won a high court case, helped by the Nautilus International union and the International Transport Workersâ€™ Federation. The Admiralty marshal agreed that the ship could be sold to pay the port and the crew: the law says the private port gets first dibs, so the sale price matters to the crew. On the day I visited, prospective buyers were inspecting, ready for next weekâ€™s auction. The captain reckons it will raise enough to cover backpay of&nbspÂ£180,000, after port charges.This isnâ€™t a one-off: foreign companies have stranded other hapless unpaid crews: one ship was recently left in Sharpness with no food. Though working in British waters between British ports, foreign ships are cheaper and use foreign labour, with a disastrous effect on British sailors. The US requires all internal port-to-port ships to be US-built and crewed â€“ and there is nothing to stop Britain demanding all such UK shipping is EU-flagged. Instead, Britain has lobbied against tighter EU rules, even though the shipping industry is a prime example of the damage done by an unfettered free market. Only a third of British-owned ships fly a British red ensign the rest use low-pay countriesâ€™ flags of convenience.Thereâ€™s no chance that the UK will take back control of its shipping or rule its own waves after Brexit, either, since â€“ as so often â€“ Britain has been the strongest lobby in Europe against reform â€“ while issuing most â€œcertificates of equivalent competencyâ€ to foreign mariners.The romance of seafaring traditions on this sceptred isle was the leitmotif of Brexiteer nationalism. Our island story, they said, never truly belonged in Europe. Once free of Brussels, the nation of Sir Francis Drake will buccaneer across the seven seas, bringing home untold new traded wealth from new worlds.In the real world of pirates and buccaneers, Brexit has just caused Britain to lose the London anti-piracy headquarters of the EU naval force, handing over to Spain and the French port of Brest. Thatâ€™s despite its success in combating Somali pirates off the Horn of Africa, with only one attack so far this year. The European commission says the UK must be treated as a non-EU country without the same access to EU security databases and military procurement programmes. So as our Major General Charlie Strickland hands over to Spainâ€™s Vice-Admiral Antonio Martorelli Lacave, who exactly is&nbsptaking&nbspback control of what?And in yet another Brexit glancing blow, and more jobs lost, the EU is deregistering three UK shipyards for use as shipbreakers to recycle EU-registered ships.All these â€œtechnicalâ€ Brexit mishaps fall below the news radar, but once you lift the stone in any industry, myriad misfortunes appear. As all workforces are left dangling, seafarers too have no idea whether EU maritime health and safety standards will be upheld post-Brexit. Britainâ€™s cavalier free-market attitude towards its shipping industry suggests more deregulation.Next time the offshore wind industry proclaims the good news that it is close to profit without subsidy, ask whose ships service those wind farms â€“ and whether their crews are subject to UK laws and pay rates. Companies get away with counting offshore wind farms and oil rigs as outside British jurisdiction. But their profits shouldnâ€™t come from undercutting UK crews with pay rates no British-based crew could live on. The unions talk of policymakersâ€™ â€œsea-blindnessâ€ over Brexit.Captain Rastogi, son of an Indian navy commodore, has had to guard his ship to stop it being claimed as abandoned. Confined to Great Yarmouth wharf, he is taken aback by the townâ€™s poverty. The other surprise, he says, is Britainâ€™s lost sense of the sea and its once great&nbspshipping industry.Brexiteers make cunning use of the emotional tug of our seafaring history, but the global freedoms they promise threaten to be merely for employers to take more control over pay and conditions.

title: thanks mamma mia cheesy pop culture is just the refuge we need
story: From Mamma Mia to Queer Eye and To All the Boys Iâ€™ve Loved Before, itâ€™s clear: joy is cool againLast month I went with my husband and father to watch Mamma Mia: Here We Go Again, a gloriously silly paean to Swedish pop music, the Mediterranean (a postcard version of it, anyway) and the pleasure of watching famous people burst â€“ without any evident embarrassment â€“ into song and dance. Dad said he was in need of a pick-me-up, and exclaimed after the film: â€œIt was a hoot!â€He seemed to echo the thoughts of many critics, who wrote about Mamma Mia as if they were starved of fresh air and sunshine, and in desperate need of some light. â€œHere We Go Again is uncomplicated joy in complicated, despairing times,â€ wrote Vanity Fairâ€™s Richard Lawson. â€œItâ€™s hot, itâ€™s muggy and the news is an ever-widening gyre of flaming airborne chili-festival Porta Potties,â€ conceded NPRâ€™s Glen Weldon, â€œso how about we forgo a review that seeks to advance any cool, objective argument on the relative cinematic worth of Mamma Mia! Here We Go Again.â€In the last 10 years the developed world has been through a global recession, several particularly hostile and isive election cycles, Brexit, fake news, the #MeToo moment and far-right political parties gaining traction all over the world. Why wouldnâ€™t I want to watch Colin Firth and Stellan Skarsgard writhe around the bow of a boat to â€œDancing Queenâ€? I left the theatre with a serotonin high I havenâ€™t felt watching a television show or movie in years. I barely remember the original Mamma Mia film but I donâ€™t think I had the same reaction to it â€“ the exhilaration of escape and enjoyment in weird and difficult times. Last week Peter Kavinsky became the Internetâ€™s Boyfriend when we all watched Netflixâ€™s To All the Boys Iâ€™ve Loved Before, in which a teenage girl finds that love letters to her crushes have been made public. Itâ€™s sweet, affectionate and relaxing watching two young people fall into what seems like a healthy and loving relationship (imagine!). Itâ€™s a much better film than Mamma Mia, but the response to it is similarly effusive. And the message is plain: emotional catharsis is cool again. Escapism is cool again. Joy is cool again.â€œItâ€™s brought about a softness in its audience that feels radical â€“ a direct response both to a dangerous and inhospitable political climate,â€ Alanna Bennett wrote on Thursday for Buzzfeed. Sophia Benoit wrote in GQ that weâ€™re all a little â€œhorny for wholesomeâ€.â€œWholesome wasnâ€™t always this appealing, so why now? Just look at the world around us,â€ she said.We might have liked these films if they came out 10 years ago but I donâ€™t think the response to them would have been so enthusiastic if I had not spent the past few years watching the news every day with horror and revulsion. Lily Jamesâ€™ breathless cartwheeling through an orange grove might have come off as painfully corny if I had not been deep into the comments section of a Facebook news post hundreds of times over the last decade. Now it looks like something Iâ€™d like to be doing.I used to love Handmaidâ€™s Tale and Mad Men and The Dark Knight. But dystopian fiction and cynical dramas feel less palatable as we veer increasingly close to the real thing. Iâ€™m less eager to see pop culture that exposes the worst of our society when itâ€™s already made so plain before us in a never-ending feed of bad news, angry argument and hate speech.Thereâ€™s nothing that signifies our need for predictable triumph more than the Rom-Com Renaissance, the return of the sweet and inevitable happy ending. Weâ€™re now so much more gleeful about films like Netflixâ€™s Set It Up and Crazy Rich Asians.Itâ€™s not just Mamma Mia getting the â€œoh well, we all need a little joyâ€ treatment. Take the reception to Netflixâ€™s Queer Eye reboot. â€œ2018 has the TV it needs,â€ declared the . â€œThereâ€™s something cathartic about its Purple America spirit, contrived and reductive as it can be,â€ wrote the New York Times. What a relief to cry, to connect and to wrap up the issues that ide us into an easily digestible 30-minute television show that we can binge watch on a Saturday.The New Yorkerâ€™s Robin Wright found â€œhopeâ€ in Americaâ€™s Got Talent. So much for the days of Simon Cowellâ€™s caustic takes. Whatâ€™s en vogue now is Nailed It, Netflixâ€™s warm-hearted show about baking disasters, the gentle cosiness of The Great British Baking Show and co-workers who love each other on Brooklyn 99. Even a rather negative review of Making It, Amy Poehler and Nick Offermanâ€™s purposefully feel-good show about crafting, by the Washington Postâ€™s Hank Steuver, said: â€œChildren are in cages, thermometers are rising, ice caps are melting. We take mental and emotional refuge wherever we can find it, armed with glue guns.â€It seems, in 2018, that weâ€™re craving comfort pop culture like we crave comfort food.If you believe, like I do, that things we watch and enjoy are a reflection of who we are as a society â€“ what we value and what is important â€“ then what we weâ€™re really valuing today is a little break from reality.

title: ways activists stay cheerful refugee women hope
story: I work with refugee women, and know how hard it can be to stay optimistic. Even small positive steps should be celebratedâ€œLeftwing people are always sad because they mind dreadfully about their causes, and the causes are always going so badly.â€ So said the Nancy Mitford heroine who fell in love with a communist, and there is an awful ring of truth to her words. That sadness has started to seem relentless lately. I wonâ€™t parse the reasons, since my readers will know them all too well. Suffice it to say that the headlines are constantly terrible, and the unreported detail often worse. Campaigns that start with energy keep getting dragged&nbspdown into factions and splinters, mud-slinging and taunts. And sometimes personal tragedies align with political setbacks in a way that feels impossible to rise above. One of the most powerful influences in my political as well as my private life has been my mother, who first took me to a protest in 1967 at Aldermaston when I was three months old, and later introduced me to feminism. A&nbspmonth after she died last year I went to a womenâ€™s march alone and stood there rain- and tear-streaked, feeling as if Iâ€™d lost my compass.Keeping hope alive is not, therefore, something that&nbsphas felt easy recently. But it also feels essential. I spend my working life alongside refugee women, and being with marginalised women teaches me that stepping out of the political arena would be a terrifically privileged step to take. It isnâ€™t possible to suggest to women who are fighting for their basic right to survive that they could just practise self-care, eat more chia seeds and&nbspdo&nbspmore&nbspyoga.Iâ€™m not saying that political activism has to dominate your life. All well and good if thatâ€™s what you choose, but for me and probably for most, the tally of a life well spent will be skewed more to family and friends, love and laughter, than to demos and meetings. But stepping away from activism completely doesnâ€™t feel OK, not when so many people are teetering on the brink of disaster. I donâ€™t want to lose touch with the possibility of a better future, even if the change each of us can make is very limited right now. So, here are three things Iâ€™ve learned that help me to stay in touch with hope.The first is completely obvious but weirdly hard to do. Instead of being active online, be active in everyday life â€“ it can be a tonic. As Gloria Steinem said, â€œObviously, there are huge advantages to the web, but it is not the same as being together in a room â€¦ You cannot empathise with each other in the same way as when you&nbspuse all five senses.â€Sitting with people rather than their online avatars helps you to see what you can do together despite your differences. You learn to shift your point of view rather than entrench it you recognise the integrity of othersâ€™ motives. And then when things do get bitter or your campaign fails, there are people around you whose support you can count on.In the work I do with refugee women, weâ€™ve set up a weekly centre where women can get support and build skills to advocate for change themselves. There are tons of similar initiatives throughout the country that provide different narratives from the dominant political themes. While we mustnâ€™t mistake sticking-plaster solutions for real change, itâ€™s heartening to see how people are getting together to show that another world is possible.I donâ€™t mean that we should be complacent and give up as soon as a little milestone is achieved, but a bit of progress is something from which to take heart. Itâ€™s weird that the left can be so reluctant to celebrate our own wins, when our history&nbspgives us so many reasons to hope. I can be a real bore about feminist history, banging on to&nbspyounger women not to forget their foremothers, but&nbspI&nbspdo it for good reason â€“ so that people can see how it&nbspisnâ€™t unrealistic, but totally in line with reality, to expect improvements in the current&nbspsituation.After all, there is still progress happening here and now, despite the torrents of awfulness. There is the rise of awareness triggered by #MeToo that has been such a boost for the womenâ€™s movement. And even in the beleaguered refugee movement, persistent campaigning against detention in the UK has resulted in small policy reforms and some pilots for wider change. Not a revolution, not yet, but an increase&nbspin humanity for some of the most vulnerable people in our&nbspsociety, and something worth holding on&nbspto as we try to move forwards.Iâ€™d love to hear more on why others are staying in the struggle: the practical steps people are taking or the solidarity they are building. Because unless we start to build more positive stories, the same headlines of despair will dominate our future as well as our present.â€¢ Natasha Walter is director of Women for Refugee Women and author of Living Dolls: The Return of Sexism

title: bring back work visas overseas graduates say uk universities
story: International student numbers in UK â€˜flatliningâ€™ as it fails to compete against likes of US British universities have called on the government to reintroduce a visa that would allow overseas students to stay in the country to work for up to two years after graduation.They say it would give the UK a competitive edge over rival countries and help it maintain the 450,000 international students, 134,835 of them EU-born, who come to study in Britain every year.Universities UK, the sectorâ€™s umbrella body, said in a briefing to parliament on Tuesday: â€œThe UK remains an extremely popular destination for international students, attracting more students from abroad except the much larger US. â€œHowever, the UKâ€™s closest competitors, such as the USA, Australia, France and Germany, all continue to grow at a faster rate than the UK.â€Launching proposals for a time-limited visa, Sir Steve Smith, the vice-chancellor of Exeter University and chairman of Universities UKâ€™s international policy network, said the visa would be an important source of soft power in the post-Brexit era.He acknowledged the governmentâ€™s long-held pledge to reduce net migration to the â€œtens of thousandsâ€, but said reintroducing a special post-study visa would send a â€œhell of a signalâ€ to the rest of the world that Britain was a welcoming country.â€œI think we are in danger of losing our position as one of the world leaders in international education,â€ he said. â€œThe market is buoyant, but the UK is flatlining in terms of international students.â€œThe UK as a country needs to make it clear that international students are absolutely welcome. I think now is the time, when we are 29 weeks from Brexit allegedly, to make a grand statement about welcoming in a new era where global talent can come to this country, study, work afterwards and thereby deal with the number-one issue with the economy, which is productivity, allowing those skilled workers enter the workforce.â€In 2012, the UK abandoned the post-study visa that had allowed graduates to stay and work in the country for two years, as the then home secretary, Theresa May, led a crackdown on student overstayers.He pointed out that the US and Canada allow students to stay for three years after graduating, while Australia, often cited as a role model for immigration by Brexiters, allows them to stay for four.A government-commissioned report on the impact of Brexit on the labour market is due to be published in autumn by the migration advisory committee.Vivienne Stern, the director of Universities UK International, said: â€œThis is explicitly not a route to settlement.â€She recognised that the Home Office was unlikely to open the gates to immigration in the current environment, but said the organisation wanted to lodge the proposal â€œin case the opportunity opens upâ€ for a post-study visa once the report is published.Universities want the post-study visa to be unrestricted allowing graduates to seek jobs without a sponsor with colleges monitoring graduates for compliance.A spokesman for the Home Office said it recognised the the cultural and financial contribution which international students make to the UK  which was why they allowed students to stay if they got a graduate level job get an internship or apply to set up a business in the UK.Universities UK pointed out that this is restricted as students must find a job with a salary of at least Â£20,800 at an employer with a Tier 2 sponsor licence within four months of completing their course, or find sponsorship as an entrepreneur. PhD students are separately able to stay for up to 12 months following completion of their degree.

title: stories 100 teachers coming to stage jess green burning books
story: Her poem Dear Mr Gove got 300k views on YouTube. Now Jess Green has written a playKat is a bushy tailed newly qualified teacher raring to start imbuing the pupils of Hurstville Community College â€“ the comprehensive on the estate to which the Teach First programme has assigned her â€“ with her passion for English.But she canâ€™t even get the youngsters to sit down in class, let alone enthuse them, and after only a week is thinking of packing it in. The head announces a new marking policy via Tannoy, a member of staff has gone missing and her middle-class mother has told friends her daughter is travelling rather than admit she is teaching in&nbspa&nbspcomprehensive.â€œWhat would Jeremy do?â€ asks Janine, a fellow teacher, as she mocks Katâ€™s Labour credentials. â€œHave you tried explaining to them the value of a good education?â€ asks Mrs Sisley, the school librarian prone to googling books and incinerating them if thereâ€™s too much sex and violence, even if it is Shakespeare.These are some of the scenes in Burning Books, an Arts Council-supported play that grew out of a poetry and music show of the same name that poet Jess Green first took to the Edinburgh Festival in 2014.Michael Gove had just ended a four-year stint as one of the most controversial education secretaries of recent times and Greenâ€™s poem Dear Mr Gove, a searing evocation of modern teaching, had struck a nerve among teachers, with 300k YouTube views. The hundreds of emails she received from teachers confirmed Greenâ€™s view that their mental health and wellbeing were at risk from the unreasonable demands of the job.Green has never taught, but comes from a family of teachers, has worked in schools and has friends who are or have been teachers. Her mother retired last year after 40 years in teaching, 10 as a head of a comprehensive school. Her sister is a teacher progressing towards senior leadership, as is her brother-in-law.When Janine (played by Therese Collins) remembers her early days of teaching â€“ two-hour lunch breaks she used for swimming shopping the pub with colleagues on Friday â€“ Green is raiding her motherâ€™s earliest professional memories.When Janine recalls what made her tear up her letter of resignation, written when she felt she couldnâ€™t cope any more, Green is telling the story of one of the 100 teachers she interviewed before writing the play. The teacher had tutored a boy in GCSE maths during her lunch breaks. His mother was an addict who had thrown him out at the age of 12, and police found him five days later sleeping in a skip with his dog and addicted to sniffing glue. He went into care, but managed a grade C in GCSE maths. The teacher didnâ€™t see him again until five years later, at a department store, where he was flourishing on a management training course. He said he couldnâ€™t have done it without her: â€œNo one ever told me I could do anything before you did.â€ Her resignation letter was binned.During Greenâ€™s early 20s she was a part-time school librarian in Leicester, and the conversations in the staffroom gave her a bleak view of what the profession was coping with. Later, when she delivered poetry workshops in schools across the country, she realised the problems were widespread â€“ and the idea of an artistic piece was born.â€œThe conversations were always the same. It was at the height of Michael Gove. The curriculum was so vast it was impossible to cover in a year. Teachers were having to send kids into exams when they hadnâ€™t been able to cover all the material. And they were being constantly vilified, told that the job was cushy with long holidays and big pensions. If kids did well in exams, it was because the exams were too easy. If they did badly, the teachers were bad. Then they started to bring in unqualified teachers, including ex-military personnel for discipline. It was all suggesting that teaching was easy and that anybody could do it. It was undervaluing teachers. This made me very, very cross.â€At the Edinburgh Fringe this year Green has been named the BBCâ€™s Slam Champion after beating 30 other of the countryâ€™s top performance poets with her show A Self Help Guide to Being in Love With Jeremy Corbyn. To her delight, the man himself came to meet her when he was in Edinburgh.As for Burning Books, Green is glad her dark but often humorous play will give voice to some of the frustrations teachers face â€“ and hopes those in power will listen. â€œI hope it adds to a very important conversation about teachers. About their mental health and welfare,â€ she says. â€œAnd about the need for an education system that fits all, not just a small number.â€Touring from September to the end of November. Details at jessgreenpoetburning-books

title: teachers national education service
story: Labour has promised an NHS-type system for education. What should its priorities be? We asked Michael Wilshaw, Danny Dorling, Frank Cottrell-Boyce and othersBook review: A Clarion Call, by Melissa BennLabour has published its plans for a â€œcradle to graveâ€ National Education Service and will unveil further details of its policy at its annual conference in Liverpool this month. It wants the NES to transform education into a right instead of a privilege, so everyone expects the same standard, as with healthcare in the National Health Service. But what would any incoming government need to do to create a truly national service? We ask people involved in education what their priorities would be.â€œI want to see radical change, not short-term, piecemeal measures and I am not sure I am seeing it in the policy at the moment. There should be a commitment to a broad and balanced, engaging curriculum with creativity at its heart, rather than at the margins. All children should be being taught critical learning skills, problem solving and political and social awareness, rather than getting a different curriculum depending on whether they are advantaged or disadvantaged. Reciting lists of kings and queens just doesnâ€™t do it. I also want to see a reversal of the academy and free school programme and schools brought back into democratically accountable public sector management.â€Diane Reay is emeritus professor of sociology of education at the University of Cambridgeâ€œAnyone drawing up an NES should take a long, hard look at the way the super-sizing of privilege has become a cancer on the body politic. Eton, for instance, seems to have done more damage to our national life than any single institution since the heyday of South Yorkshire police.â€œAnd end the whole craven notion that education should somehow be responsive to the demands of the world of work. No one has a clue what work will look like â€“ or if there will be any â€“ in 10 years, let alone 20.â€Frank Cottrell Boyce is a screenwriter and novelistâ€œThe differential in performance between secondary schools in the north, Midlands and south of England is far too great and shows little sign of diminishing. This canâ€™t be explained by economic factors, because there is very little difference in performance at primary school level.â€œThe massive expansion of the academies and free schools programme has marginalised local authorities and the role of local politicians. Iâ€™m no fan of local authorities because many of them didnâ€™t sufficiently support and challenge schools when they had full control of the system. My concern now is that local oversight of standards is just as patchy under the newly created regional schools commissioners, who seem to come and go with worrying frequency. We need local politicians, particularly the new mayors, to champion their schools and know whatâ€™s going on in their area.â€œThis country is failing half its future. Technical and vocational education for those youngsters who donâ€™t progress to traditional A-level courses and university has not been good enough for many years and certainly not up to the standard of many of our international competitors. These young people are too often served up inadequate programmes of study and training at school, further education institutions and apprenticeships. This is compounded by inconsistent careers education and guidance.â€œWe urgently need a strong political figure at senior ministerial level to oversee the skills agenda and work across the departments of education, business and employment as well as the CBI and chambers of commerce to ensure key stakeholders work together.â€Sir Michael Wilshaw is a former head of Ofsted and professor of education at St Maryâ€™s University, Twickenhamâ€œNursery education must not be run for profit. It may take five years to ensure nursery education in the UK is profit-free but it is entirely possible. All children should start school on their fifth birthday to get rid of the summer-born problem. Every school in those counties that have kept selection should be renamed â€œgrammar schoolsâ€ and the 11-plus should go.â€œAcademy trusts must be disbanded after the fraud investigations are completed and school management returned to geographical areas. I would like to see groups of six or so neighbouring secondary schools with a single senior management team, democratically chosen. Teachers would be able to sack their senior managers. Thatâ€™s how the governing body of an Oxford college works and it keeps them on their toes.â€Danny Dorling is professor of human geography at the University of Oxfordâ€œThe NES must ensure that students, whatever their background, are able to fully participate in education. This will mean examining the barriers faced by some students, such as the crippling cost of living, and finding solutions, such as the reintroduction of maintenance grants. We will also need a set of new initiatives to improve access for black students. The NES should pledge to tackle the attainment gap of black students in our further and higher education systems.â€Shakira Martin is the president of the National Union of Students â€œIf Labour wishes to create a truly national education service it must deal with the private schools. A gilded class of privileged children help themselves to the best university places and top jobs at the expense of state school students. Abolishing the VAT exemption on private school fees is a good start.â€œBut a national education service must also make use of the big public schools and their wealthy endowments, which were established to educate the poor. Incorporating the 600,000 private school pupils into an NES would not only be cost-neutral but add value to the state school estate. Having these families cheering on their children shoulder to shoulder with other parents would help raise standards across the state sector while making our communities stronger.â€Robert Verkaik is author of Posh Boysâ€œEducation should be about young people and adults finding their strengths and their potential â€“ what it means to be their best selves. Now it is being driven by fear and all the emphasis on data and results is fracturing the system and working against the reason most people came into the profession. Children are being made to feel that education is about exam grades and headteachers are under enormous pressure from the completely flawed accountability systems.â€Viv Grant is a former headteacher who coaches other headsâ€œAbolishing tuition fees creates the opportunity for a fresh start. A new funding council for adults, apprenticeships, further and higher education should be created to provide vital investment in the peopleâ€™s education and skills. Generously resourced, it must replace tuition fees pound for pound with government grants. Institutional autonomy, as well as academic freedom, must be strengthened and strictly respected as a vital ingredient in a democratic society. Legislation should be passed to ensure that education at all levels is provided by not-for-profit independent institutions, whose students and staff have a real say in their institutionâ€™s governance, alongside community representatives.â€David Green is the vice-chancellor of the University of Worcester Jules White is headteacher of Tanbridge House School, West Sussexâ€œI would like artificial intelligence to be taken more seriously, something the government has failed to do until very recently. AI will totally transform British schools and universities within a decade. It will assist them to overcome the many inherent problems with the factory model of education that has existed for so many years and provide a personalised â€˜teacherâ€™ for every student, who will be able to progress at their inidual level of understanding in each subject.â€Sir Anthony Seldon is vice-chancellor of the University of Buckinghamâ€œWe need a fully comprehensive, free, cradle-to-grave education system with provision for part and full-time learning. This should be democratically controlled by local education authorities and made available through neighbourhood learning campuses bringing together schools, adult education and associated services such as libraries.â€œThere should be objective teaching that uses scientifically accurate language on sex and gender and encourages students to understand the difference between biological sex and socially constructed gender roles. This is particularly important at a time when increasing numbers of young people are self-identifying as transgender.â€Selina Todd is professor of modern history at the University of Oxford and president of the Socialist Educational Association

title: supermarket sales of organic food and drink continue to rise
story: Exclusive: organic fresh produce and dairy are now worth a record Â£2.2bn a yearDespite an exceptionally cold winter and a hot, dry summer which have played havoc with crops, organic fresh produce and dairy sales remain the main drivers fuelling growth of the overall market, now worth a record Â£2.2bn.Supermarket shoppers spent Â£1.5bn on organic food and drink, including baby products, in the 52 weeks to the end of June, according to new independent data.That represents sales through â€œBritish retail outletsâ€ â€“ predominantly the big supermarkets but with a small percentage from chains such as Nisa and Costcutter. It does not include independent organic retailers or vegetable box schemes. The figures provide a half-year â€˜progress reportâ€™ before publication of the sectorâ€™s detailed Organic Market Report and full breakdown in February.â€œWe know that interest in organic food has been growing in recent years and itâ€™s great to see that farmers continue to be rewarded for growing food as it should be, with no artificial additivies, fewer pesticides, no GM and with the highest standards of animal welfareâ€ said Liz Bowles, Soil Associationâ€™s head of farming. â€œSales in 2018 are continuing to grow although all UK agricultural businesses are suffering from the unprecedented drought and heat which has affected large parts of the globe.â€Sales of organic food and drink have bounced back after plummeting following the recession. But the market is still dwarfed by the size of the overall food and drink sector â€“ the largest manufacturing segment in the UK and now worth Â£28.8bn according to the the Food and Drink Federation.

title: jose mourinho the nice one radical rebrand manchester united
story: There may have been more rivetingly awkward televised football interviews in the last few seasons than JosÃ© Mourinhoâ€™s rivetingly awkward post-match exchange with the BBCâ€™s Juliette Ferrington on Match of the Day 2 on Sunday. But not many of them. And none as rivetingly awkward in quite the same way â€“ awkward to an end, pointedly awkward, awkward with a certain kind of gain in mind and above all, just really awkward.Ferrington put it to Mourinho that Romelu Lukaku had told her his manager was a totally different man on the training pitch. At which point it all went a bit fuzzy. Mourinho paused. He took a breath. Something weird seemed to be happening to his face. The eyes were the same, still ablaze with the familiar righteous fury, the eyes of a notoriously vengeful star federation president about to unleash the unimaginable fury of his planetary destructor beam on the cowering scum of this peace-loving rural idyll.But Mourinhoâ€™s mouth was doing something strange, curling just a little at the edges, in what appeared to be an unaccustomed â€œupâ€ direction, almost like a smile. â€œPeople who know me, they like me,â€ he mumbled eventually, a bead of sweat breaking out on his forehead as through sheer force of will he summoned up what might have been a genial twinkle. This was something new. This was novel, and even a little disturbing. This was JosÃ© being nice.It is, of course, necessary to issue general apologies at this point. Yes, itâ€™s another JosÃ© Mourinho article. Letâ€™s face it, this is to be expected at the start of a Premier League season that has so far been a fairly room temperature affair elsewhere. Like United, Mourinho remains an object of fascination, in part because he has always intended this to be the case. And partly also because this latest gambit, new Nice JosÃ©, JosÃ© of the people uniting the fans, is so clearly a plan, something that has been discussed and settled on to change the weather around the club.This was evident from the moment at the end of the Tottenham game when Mourinho stayed to applaud the home crowd very publicly, smiling like a shark at a birthday party. Mourinho was there again applauding the fans at Burnley, as he generally does, but more pointedly this time, a surprisingly urgent figure suddenly, transformed into a footballing version of Victor Laszlo in Casablanca, an elegantly turned out man of the people, populist in a grey zip-neck sweater. The players are on board too. â€œUnited now more than everâ€ David de Gea tweeted on Thursday night. A few hours later Eric Bailly went with â€œNow More than Ever â€¦ Togetherâ€. Jesse Lingard offered the hashtag #UnitedTogether.This feels like a welcome move on many levels, both personal and tactical. United were expected to beat Burnley at Turf Moor. Sundayâ€™s performance may mean nothing at all, a brief spike in a parabola of sullen decline that most assume will culminate in a toxic farewell within the year. But taken together with the first half against Tottenham last Monday there was something structurally different, an altered angle of approach.Persona, attitude, the styling of his managerial personality: this is important to Mourinho, a major part of his professional voodoo. Finding an approach, a set of tactics and a persona that fits with his players is key. Something about the way Mourinho has presented himself in the last week speaks to the way he has done this, successfully, in the past.The fact remains Mourinho has only ever really been his best self, only achieved extraordinary things when he has been the underdog, when his team have come from outside the elite to beat the elite. Most obviously at Porto, but also at Internazionale where a mixed team of might-bes and old lags won a first European Cup in 45 years. Even Chelsea were a club ready to be led in 2004, moneyed arrivistes driven on to a first League title since the days of Ted Drake.Mourinho got so good at managing top-level underdog clubs he was allowed to manage top-level overdog clubs. And it is here the congealment set in. Mourinho wants to disrupt, to destroy your expensively acquired plans and impose his own will. It requires constant drilling, players who are willing to suffer and an audience willing to take pleasure in a little darkness. This best Mourinho was a populist outsider. At Real Madrid and now at United he has been an un-populist insider, become the kind of man he had always hated, or sought to bring down.And so on to new Nice JosÃ©, the populist underdog, the unity candidate. To his credit, and however awkwardly, Mourinho is making efforts to unite his base, to create a winning spirit, to re-forge those bonds. Best of all this coincided at Burnley, and for half a game against Tottenham, with a more JosÃ©-looking team, a return to the pared-down, hard-running football of his best XIs.Lukaku played less with his back to goal, and instead ran with real verve and intelligence into space on either flank. At times he was devastating, an old school Mourinho-style leader from the front in the style of Diego Milito or Didier Drogba. Behind him Paul Pogba had the right kind of entourage, two defensive midfielders allowing him to pass more, make the play, show his range of angles. Last season Pogba was 19th on the list of accurate long passes from central midfield in the Premier League. Currently he is fourth this season. Against Burnley his link-ups with Lukaku were instant and incisive, direct football in the best Mourinho sense.Two years ago Antonio Conte reconfigured his Chelsea team to devastating effect over the autumn international break. It may be too much to expect something similar. But Mourinho is at least trying something else here, a little grudging charm where the snarls had begun to drag everyone down, and a slight, perhaps incidental modification of his team along simpler, more classically Mourinho lines in its past two matches.The charm offensive may, in the end, prove a bridge too far but at least there is some hope, whatever the outcome of his third season, that Mourinho will not leave United without ever having really wrestled this team into something resembling one of his own.

title: funding circle launches 2bn stock market flotation plan
story: Companyâ€™s three co-founders in line for combined windfall of Â£70mThree friends who met at university are in line for a combined windfall of Â£70m after revealing plans for a Â£2bn float of Funding Circle, the British peer-to-peer lending business they founded eight years ago.Funding Circle, which allows small firms to tap into a pool of money provided by thousands of investors, aims to raise Â£300m in a stock market float valuing the company at up to Â£1.95bn.Funding Circle offers loans of up to Â£1m to firms that want to raise capital quickly or have been turned down by a bank. Its model, which relies on sophisticated data analytics, has resulted in the issuance of Â£5bn of loans since 2010 by matching 50,000 businesses directly with 80,000 investors.The company said it would use the Â£300m it hoped to raise to fund expansion into new countries and to â€œengender trustâ€ with borrowers, lenders and regulators. It added that raising the cash would help it pursue growth without worrying about profitability in the medium term.Despite rapid revenue growth, up from Â£51m in 2016 to Â£94.5m in 2017, the company racked up losses of more than Â£70m during those two years.Desai said the company was only losing money because of the cost of building its business overseas, insisting that its UK operation was already profitable. He said the company would become more profitable as it reduced investments and started to rely more on repeat borrowers, who cost less to acquire and to vet.According to Funding Circleâ€™s last set of accounts, revenues have been boosted as the company stepped into the space vacated by banks showing caution about lending amid economic uncertainty caused by Brexit. Revenues nearly doubled last year and are on course to show further growth for 2018, with half-year revenues already at Â£63m compared with Â£41m in the first six months of 2017.Desai said Funding Circle would survive in the event of an economic crash that could affect the ability of borrowers to pay back investors.He said the firm had deployed the same stress-testing criteria used by the Prudential Regulatory Authority, a UK regulator that monitors the health of the banking system, to track the resilience of banks.

title: michel legrand interview film soundtrack legend composer
story: He wrote the soundtracks to some of the greatest films ever, winning Oscars and partying with the stars. As he hits Britain, the 86-year-old Frenchman recalls fights with his mother â€“ and benders with Miles DavisA few minutes before Iâ€™m due to press the buzzer on the door of Michel Legrandâ€™s apartment building in Paris, the announcement of Aretha Franklinâ€™s death comes through. He greets the news with a sigh. Many years ago, he remembers, he had a plan to team Aretha with Ray Charles on a new recording of Porgy and Bess, updating the version made by Louis Armstrong and Ella Fitzgerald in 1958. He sighs again. It would have been wonderful, he says.His anecdote hardly comes as a surprise. Legrand seems to have worked, at one time or another, with practically every figure of consequence in popular music and film since the end of the second world war, from Maurice Chevalier to Sting and from Orson Welles to Jean-Luc Godard. And he has stories about all of them.The interview was supposed to take place in his country home, the ChÃ¢teau de la Mothe, south of Paris, where he lives with his third wife, the actor Macha MÃ©ril, whom he married in 2014, four decades after they first met. When a dental emergency forced a postponement, he asked to meet instead at his apartment in the Marais. He needed to be in Paris, he said, for a meeting about a new theatre production of Peau dâ€™Ã¢ne, a film he made with Jacques Demy almost 50 years ago, a musical that followed their great box-office successes with Les Parapluies de Cherbourg and Les Demoiselles de Rochefort. â€œBig production,â€ he says. â€œBig orchestra. Some writing.â€At 86, Legrand continues to live up to the saying that if you want something done, ask a busy person. He is a little frail now, and occasionally he has trouble remembering the name of a friend or a film from long ago. But nothing â€“ not even an illness that struck him during a flight on a Russian airliner, putting him in a coma â€“ will make him pause to rest on the laurels amassed, in particular, from writing the scores for more than 200 films, winning Oscars and Grammys while lodging such songs as The Windmills of Your Mind (from The Thomas Crown Affair) and What Are You Doing the Rest of Your Life? (from The Happy Ending) in the global memory.Towards the end of the interview he tells me that he now ides his professional life into distinct chapters. The first was in the 1950s, when he was an arranger for famous singers, including Chevalier and Jacques Brel. In the 60s he wrote music for important films by the French new wave directors â€“ Godard, Demy, AgnÃ¨s Varda and so on. Then he moved to the US and scored dozens of Hollywood movies, from Joseph Loseyâ€™s The Go-Between and Wellesâ€™s F for Fake to Steve McQueenâ€™s Le Mans and Robert Altmanâ€™s PrÃªt-Ã -porter, as well as popping back to Europe to work with Andrzej Wajda, Claude Lelouch and others. Next he concentrated for several years on writing musicals. â€œWhen I hit 80,â€ he concludes, â€œI knew that the last chapter of my work would be classical. So I wrote a piano concerto that I recorded myself, a cello concerto, a harp concerto, some sonatas. I wrote a huge ballet. Iâ€™m very proud of that. Itâ€™s a good final chapter.â€And during the last chapter â€“ if that is really what it turns out to be â€“ there is also time for a series of concerts, including one in London this month, when he will conduct orchestral arrangements of music from his soundtracks. And, no doubt, play a little piano and sing a couple of the famous songs on which he collaborated with a variety of lyricists, providing glimpses of a talent that, as he remembers, could have gone in many directions.â€œWhen I finished at the Paris Conservatoire,â€ he says, â€œI was 20 and I felt I could do everything. I could write symphonies. I could be a virtuoso classical pianist, but to do that I had to work 12 hours a day. I could be a jazz pianist â€“ I liked that very much, because youâ€™re free and I know how to improvise. I could be a singer. I could be a conductor. So I said my dream in my life is to do it all.â€â€œI taught myself to write music, so that when I was five or six years old I was very much ahead. Finally my mother saw that I was interested in the piano and nothing else. So in 1942, in the middle of the occupation, I went to the Conservatoire. You go to that building for the first time and when you open the door itâ€™s music and nothing else. I was 10 years old and I said, â€˜Thatâ€™s my world.â€™â€ Among his teachers was the celebrated Nadia Boulanger, whose later pupils included Astor Piazzolla and Philip Glass. â€œI hated her sometimes because she was so demanding, but she was extraordinary. She made me.â€Itâ€™s the story of a pivotal moment in his career. In 1954, a friend who worked at a record company told him that its US partner, Columbia Records, wanted to make an easy-listening orchestral album with a Parisian theme. None of the big-name American arrangers was interested. The 22-year-old Legrand jumped at the opportunity, despite being told that he would be paid only $200, with no royalties. I Love Paris, as it was titled, topped the charts and sold millions. So when he visited the US as Chevalierâ€™s musical director in 1958, Columbia offered compensation in the form of paying for an album of his arrangements of jazz standards featuring top American jazz musicians, including Davis. Released as Legrand Jazz, it established his credibility.He and Davis became friends and collaborated again in 1991, shortly before the trumpeterâ€™s death, on a film called Dingo, directed by Rolf de Heer. â€œMiles called me up and said, â€˜Michel, youâ€™d better bring your fucking ass to Los Angeles next week because weâ€™re doing a film. I agreed to do it on condition that you are with me.â€™ So I push all my work away. I go to his house in Malibu. We talk a lot, we drink a lot, we eat a lot. Friday arrives, the sessions are starting on Monday, and we havenâ€™t written anything yet. Miles says, â€˜We shouldnâ€™t do it.â€™ I say, â€˜Miles, thatâ€™s not nice, a young man is counting on you. OK, I have an idea. Iâ€™ll go to my hotel and Iâ€™ll compose everything in four days and four nights. On Wednesday Iâ€™ll record the orchestra and Saturday you come.â€™ He says, â€˜Michel â€“ I knew you were a genius.â€™ That bastard. An adventure! I love this very much.â€Before saying goodbye he returns to the subject of the London concert, in which he hopes to conduct his compositions against projections of the scenes they originally accompanied. When I mention the highly charged seven-and-a-half-minute chess game between Steve McQueen and Faye Dunaway in The Thomas Crown Affair, he mentions that the director, Norman Jewison, cut the scene to fit the music, which begins with a solo harp and ends with a big band playing a jazz waltz.â€œI want to try to explain what happened, to tell the audience what Iâ€™ve done,â€ he says. â€œEvery movie that Iâ€™ve scored, Iâ€™ve tried to be original, to be different from what weâ€™re used to listening to. When I write music, my music talks. Itâ€™s not a music that says nothing, a tapestry where nothing happens, like most of the composers. I think Iâ€™ve been an adventurer â€“ in life, in my work, too.â€

title: aping each other how similar are humans and orangutans
story: From umbrella-making to learning how to self-medicate, we share plenty of skills with our fellow great apesWhen scientists talk about animals using tools, theyâ€™re not normally talking about the implements you might use to knock up some shelves. But while animals generally confine themselves to bashing things with the odd rock, in extraordinary footage broadcast last year as part of the BBCâ€™s Spy in the Wild series, a wild female orangutan is seen using a saw she has found outside a hut to cut through a log â€“ even pausing to blow away sawdust before continuing.In the wild, orangutans use large sticks to get at honey inside logs, shelter from the rain by fashioning umbrellas out of leaves and hold bunches of leaves in front of their mouths to lower the pitch of their calls to scare off predators. Captive orangutans have been taught to use hammers, screwdrivers and keys.Researchers have even shown that orangutans learn and generate new sounds â€“ an ability until recently considered largely the preserve of humans. The ability to consciously vibrate twin bands of muscle tissue in the larynx called vocal folds â€“ important in generating many new sounds â€“ was thought to have evolved after we erged from chimpanzees, our closest great ape relatives, some 5-7m years ago.Then, an international team of researchers caught wind of reports of a male orangutan called Rocky using sounds reminiscent of the plaintive groans made by Chewbacca, of Star Wars fame, to attract the attention of his keepers at Indianapolis Zoo. In a study published in 2016, the group compared Rockyâ€™s call to other known orangutan sounds and found it to be novel.They then taught him to imitate a human who was making versions of his call at different pitches. â€œThis shows the ability to change the frequency of calls through control of the vocal folds was likely to have predated the last common ancestor of humans and orangutans,â€ says Prof Serge Wich, of Liverpool John Moores University, one of the studyâ€™s authors.Orangutans have also been shown to have human-like, long-term memories. In 2009, Danish scientists showed a group of orangutans and chimps how to retrieve a piece of banana by reaching through a slot with the longer of two sticks, and then hid the sticks in boxes in nearby rooms. Three years later, all bar one of the orangutans knew what to do to get the food in the same set-up.Just as the list of tool-using animals has grown in recent years, so too has the list of those that use plants as medicine. Lizards eat certain roots to counter snake venom, macaws consume clay to aid digestion as well as to gain minerals, and pregnant lemurs nibble tamarind and fig leaves to boost milk production. Orangutans are among a smaller group of primates that self-medicate by rubbing substances into their fur.Behavioural ecologist Helen Morrogh-Bernard, of Exeter University, and co-director of the Borneo Nature Foundation, last year reported observing child-bearing female orangutans chewing the leaves of the shrub Dracaena cantleyi to form a soapy foam that they then rub into their upper arms or legs. Chemical analysis showed it has anti-inflammatory properties. Local people use the same plant as pain relief. Unlike many other similarities between orangutans and humans, this one has cultural rather than evolutionary roots. And not in the way you might think. â€œWhen we surveyed local people,â€ says Morrogh-Bernard, â€œthey told us their ancestors started using a number of plants as medicines after seeing orangutans doing so.â€So our two species are very similar â€“ to the extent that we sometimes even have things to learn from them.Help create a movement to stop companies using dirty palm oil. title: orangutans and palm oil seven facts that explain the issues
story: From ice-cream to shampoo, palm oil is present in a multitude of consumer products. But palm oil cultivation in south-east Asia is clearing forests and contributing to the decline of orangutans. Here are the key points Think back over the past week in your life. If youâ€™ve applied lipstick, eaten toast or put on a load of washing, chances are, youâ€™ve used a product containing palm oil. Indulged in ice-cream or washed your hair? Palm oil. According to the World Wildlife Fund: â€œIt is in about half of all packaged products sold in the supermarket.â€ And itâ€™s linked to the destruction of the rainforest and many of the species that reside in it.To stop palm oil being listed as â€œvegetable oilâ€ or as one of a long list of hard to pronounce synonyms, an EU law was passed in 2014, stating that all food products containing palm oil should be labelled clearly. But the same cannot be said for cosmetics and household products in which palm oil is often used.Indonesia is home to some of the most bioerse areas in the world, including the Leuser ecosystem, the last place on Earth where Sumatran orangutans, elephants, tigers, rhinos and sun bears coexist naturally. The Tropical Heritage Rainforest of Sumatra â€“ of which the Leuser ecosystem is a part â€“ is a Unesco world heritage site, but itâ€™s still in danger from palm oil plantations, pulp production and infrastructure projects. Orangutans are keystone species, which, according to National Geographic, means they help define entire ecosystems. If a keystone species â€“ sea otters, elephants, honey bees, for example â€“ disappears, no other species can fill its shoes, and the ecosystem changes irrevocably. Mainstream media now regularly covers palm oil, campaigns such as Say No to Palm Oil have sprung up and the Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil runs a certification system, which aims to ensure all palm oil with its stamp comes from sustainably managed plantations. Genuine change is yet to occur, however, prompting campaigners to put pressure on brands that use palm oil, urging them to use their power to genuinely reform their suppliers.Help create a movement to stop companies using dirty palm oil.
