title: frestonia squatters london declare independence uk 1970s free independent
story: Created with Sketch.The Free Independent Republic of Frestonia was born of a generation who knew counterculture as much as precarious living. Now a new book collects photography and stories from the communityClick to followThe IndependentThe community designed a flag, appointed ministers of state â€“ including actor David Rappaport as foreign minister â€“ made their own postage stamps and issued visas for visitorsThere was a lot of talk, in the wake of the Brexit referendum, suggesting that London should stage its own exit from the United Kingdom, declare independence, and ask to rejoin the EU as a nation state.Ignoring for now the fact that not everyone â€“ though&nbspit might seem that way to London â€“ outside the capital voted to leave the EU, it seemed a satisfying, though jokey, postscript to the Brexit vote. Indeed, more than 180,000 Londoners signed an online petition calling for the mayor, Sadiq&nbspKhan, to â€œdeclare London independent, and apply to join the EU â€“&nbspincluding membership of the Schengen zoneâ€.But what a lot of the signatories might not have realised was that there was indeed a precedent for London seceding from the UK. Or at least, one street of the capital.&nbspWelcome to the Free Independent Republic of Frestonia. Or, whatâ€™s left of it, which these days amounts to the Frestonian Gallery, keeping the name and spirit alive of one of the most curious episodes in Londonâ€™s history. It&nbspbegan on Halloween&nbsp1977, when the residents of Freston Road in Notting Dale, West London, which was largely comprised of squats and communes, declared independence.Threatened with eviction, the squatters said they were no longer part of the UK and appealed to the United Nations to send in peacekeeping forces to prevent Greater London Council turfing them out of the homes they had claimed. They designed a flag, appointed ministers of state, and even made their own postage stamps and issued visas for visitors.The short-lived story of the Free Independent Republic of Frestonia has now been documented in a new book of photographs by one of its residents, the photographer Tony Sleep, who was resident on Freston Road from 1974.&nbspSleep describes the Frestonia experiment as â€œpart publicity stunt, part theatrical protestâ€, and adds that while it wasnâ€™t a serious attempt to break away from the UK, there was never any need to, because what became Frestonia â€œwas already on a different planetâ€.He writes in the lavish book: â€œFrestonia was rooted in the counterculture of the time. The period is now dismissed as little more than daft clothes and hair, accompanied by a great soundtrack and the invention of sex and drugs.â€œIt was, we are told, youthful self indulgence that ended badly because it was irresponsible and naive.â€Frestonian Gallery)Frestonia was born out of problems that young people will recognise today: the lack of affordable accommodation. Sleep points out that the millennial generation might have a beef with the baby boomers who grew up in the 1960s and 1970s because they had it easy, and accommodation was cheap and plentiful. Not a bit of it, he says.â€œRented flats were in very short supply, and mostly slum standard. You might achieve a rented bedsit as long as you werenâ€™t black, Irish&nbspor a dog. Then, as now, landlords wanted â€˜professionalâ€™ people.â€œCouncil housing lists were only for families, and backlogged for decades. Despite what now seem like absurdly low prices, only the wealthy and secure could obtain mortgages at a time before easy mass debts. Less than half the population owned their own homes at the start of the 1970s.â€Freston Road, where squatters and activists founded housing coop and community Frestonia&nbsp(Getty)Many of the houses on Freston Road were empty, having been condemned as unfit for human habitation, and most of the residents had been relocated to the new highrise blocks of flats that began to go up in the 1960s and 1970s. There had been a move to demolish the vacant properties, but residents in neighbouring communities had complained that they would be looking out onto swathes of barren, rubble-strewn land that would encourage flytipping, so the authorities decided to take the cheaper option and just leave the buildings standing for a while.Freston Road might have been abandoned, but that didnâ€™t mean it was unused. From 1974, squatters began to break into the empty houses and set up home there Tony Sleep, aged 24 at that time, was one of them.He recalls:&nbspâ€œSquatting is distinctly equal opportunity. If you can gain possession, itâ€™s yours. This led to an interesting mix of people who had little in common except needing somewhere to live and being poor for one reason or another. While some tried to make their new homes habitable, several houses were quickly wrecked.â€Sleep remembers well his first sight of Freston Road. Heâ€™d been living in a â€œdismal rented basementâ€ in west Kensington, but as he and his girlfriend parted company, he needed somewhere else to live, and heard about a street of empty houses. Some of his friends went to have a look and broke into two of the houses.â€œThat night I paid them a visit,â€ writes Sleep. â€œEight people, four guys, four girls, in one candlelit room, the only one that had windows. There was no toilet, no water, no electricity.â€But his friends set to work installing plumbing and wiring as best they could, found an old toilet, rescued carpets and furniture from skips, and Sleep asked if he could move in with them.By 1977 Freston Road had settled into an unorthodox community, of sorts. But the attention of the GLC wandered back to these old, abandoned homes, and the squatters were told that they were to be evicted from these properties.The council offered to place the squatters in what were considered â€œhard to letâ€ properties dotted around London, and some took the flats â€“&nbspand, says Sleep, were promptly replaced in Freston Road by other people desperate for somewhere to live.&nbspThe GLC announced its intention to bulldoze Freston Road after all, and a meeting was called, attended by 200 people. They decided â€“ inspired by the Ealing comedy Passport to Pimlico â€“ to go it alone. The Free Independent Republic of Frestonia was born. And the battle was on.The Frestonian National Anthem was written (â€œLong live Frestonia! Land of the free â€“ not the GLCâ€) and a community newspaper, The Tribal Messenger, was distributed. Frestonia made the international press, and the Daily Mirror ran a piece declaring â€œAll Hall, Frestoniaâ€. The actor David Rappaport was made foreign minister, and playwright Heathcote Williams became ambassador to the United Kingdom.It was all a bit jolly and, of course, more than a pinch of Ealing comedy. But, Sleep points out, Frestonia was also an interesting way of putting British society under the&nbspmicroscope.â€œCommunities are defined, more or less, by what people have in common,â€ he writes. â€œThatâ€™s usually class, background or aspiration, sometimes race or religion. What people have in common helps them feel safe and valued. What is different can be threatening or isive.Frestonian Gallery)â€œFamilies, on the other hand, are a matter of being stuck with people you sometimes struggle to tolerate, let alone like. Frestonia was a bit of both.â€œFrestonians were, beneath the veneer of pragmatic anarchy, from different cultures. There were the hippies, idealists of a sort. There were the punks, nihilists of a sort. And there were the itinerant street people, whose lack of youth and lost changes gave them a thread of bitterness to chew on together.â€Over the next couple of years, fighting the threat of the GLC bulldozers, the anarchic squat collective organised itself more seriously, forming the Bramley Housing Cooperative with an aim that was less about the fun of independence and more about securing the future of the Freston Road community.Eventually, the GLC won the war, and demolition of the squats began in 1983. But the Bramley Housing Cooperative, working with the Notting Hill Housing Trust, continued to fight for Freston Road as a residential area. And, ultimately, they won.Sleep says, â€œFrestonia didnâ€™t cease when the squats were demolished. How could it? They were only useful ruins. Frestonia was about the people, its improbable family.â€œIf you walk through Frestonia now, thereâ€™s little to suggest it is much different from anywhere else. Youâ€™ll find a street of small, but perhaps unusually pretty houses, built in the mid 1980s. They look carefully designed, a bit too inidual to be social housing. You may not notice the enclosed communal gardens, or the sheltered housing scheme that the coop insisted on, you wonâ€™t know the coop ensured housing for some of the more vulnerable Frestonians.â€It might be that Frestonia would be forgotten all together, but for Tony Sleepâ€™s photographic record of the people, events and houses on Freston Road in the late 1970s and early 1980s.â€˜Pop-up squatâ€™: Activists occupy property to protest Housing BillNew photography exhibition shows the tough reality of squattingChallenging consumption and overwork in a Danish communityThe name does linger on in the form of the Frestonian Gallery, opened in 2017 by Matt Incledon and Rollo Campbell, who have published Tony Sleepâ€™s photographs and recollections in Welcome To Frestonia. A pair of, in their own words, â€œitinerant art dealersâ€, they opened the gallery in The Peopleâ€™s Hall, a Victorian building that was once at the heart of Frestonia.&nbspFrestonian Gallery opened in 2017 to remember a most curious episode in Londonâ€™s history&nbsp(Tony SleepFrestonian Gallery)Becoming appraised of the story of Frestonia, they were introduced to Tony Sleep, and arranged an exhibition of his photographs. They write in their foreword: â€œIt was an exhibition unlike anything either of us had worked on previously. Each day at the gallery provided a steady stream of visitors keen to revisit and share their own personal memories of Frestonia. It would be a nice point at which to say â€˜We then decided a book of Tonyâ€™s work needs to be published...â€™ but again, in truth, the decision had been made for us already by the sheer emotional response to this unique exhibition.â€Was it all worth it for the Frestonians? Did it make a difference? Tony Sleep closes his remarkable document of this time by musing, â€œForty years on, the UK seems to have travelled in a large circle and arrived little the wiser, but probably angrier, more cynical and more ided than ever.&nbspWe are all Frestonians, on this small blue dot in the middle of nowhere. We are all one family, whether we like it or not.â€Welcome to Frestonia by Tony Sleep&nbspis published by the Frestonian Gallery (frestoniangallery), priced Â£35Free Independent Republic of FrestoniaEnter your email addressFill out this fieldregister with your social account or click here to log inAre you sure you want to submit this vote?Are you sure you want to mark this comment as inappropriate?Are you sure you want to delete this comment?

title: brexit news northern ireland irish border scotland independence latest poll
story: The majority of Northern Irish citizens would vote to scrap the border that separates the Irish Republic in the event of a hard Brexit, the poll by Deltapoll for campaign group Our Future Our Choice indicates.The survey found 52 percent would support Irish reunification after Brexit by scrapping the border which has plagued trade deal negotiations with Brussels since the June 2016 referendum.Up to 1,199 Northern Ireland citizens took part in the ballot which was conducted between August 27 and 30 and featured the question &lsquoImagine now that the UK decided to leave the EU. Under these circumstances how would you vote in a referendum on the constitutional arrangements of the island of Ireland?&rsquoMore than half said they would vote for a united Ireland compared to 39 percent said they would rather Northern Ireland remain part of the UK.                Theresa May's rejection of second Brexit vote is 'TOTALITARIAN' Up to seven percent of voters were unsure how they would answer.In the event of a hard border, 56 percent of those polled said they would vote for Irish unity, which would also see Ireland press for independence from the UK.This comes after former Sinn Fein leader Gerry Adams said an Irish unity referendum is &ldquono longer a matter of if but when.He added: &ldquoThe issue of Irish unity is now a matter of almost daily conversation. Despite the negativity of both governments there is growing support for a referendum on unity and for a united Ireland.The majority of Northern Irish citizens would vote to scrap the border post-Brexit (Image: )                Sturgeon says Scotland to GO after Brexit as UK too Brexit 'obsessed'The politician&rsquos remarks were echoed in past opinion polls, which showed support for Irish independence has been on the rise since Brexit.In January 2013, just 17 percent of Northern Ireland voted for independence while a second Ipsos Mori poll in the months after the referendum saw the figure rise to 22 percent.By the two-year anniversary of the referendum in June 2018 a Lord Ashcroft poll revealed 44 percent of Northern Irish citizens were in favour of reunification.And a second poll conducted by Deltapoll for Scots campaign group Best for Britain revealed 47 percent would vote for an independent Scotland compared to 43 percent against, with 10 percent undecided.Up to 47 percent would vote for an independent Scotland compared to 43 percent against (Image: )The survey asked 1,022 Scots, with the results fuelling speculation that Brexit could result in the breakup of the union.In the 2014 Scottish Independence referendum, the &lsquono&rsquo side won with 2,001,926 - or 53 percent - voting against Scotland becoming separate to the UK, while 1,617,989 - 44 percent - voted for independence. The turnout was 84.6 percent.When another poll was conducted two years before the EU referendum, 32 percent supported a plan for an independent Scotland.SNP deputy leader Keith Brown spoke at a national assembly in the Scottish Highlands where he stressed the importance of independence to a crowd of activists at the weekend.                 EU's plan to STOP annual changing of clocks                 Ireland to leave EU: Irexit Freedom party set up by Farage allyHe said: &ldquoA fresh case for independence is more vital than ever and that is what we are working on at the national assemblies, and with wider engagement enabling members of our party direct input and people from across the Yes movement and civic Scotland a say too.The ision of Ireland took place in May 1921 the Government of Ireland Act 1920 came into force.This saw Northern Ireland and the Irish Republic become governed by two distinct jurisdictions.

title: eu news sir hugh dowding letter brexit eu uk latest
story: RAF pilot Sir Hugh Dowding said in a private letter to Lord Beaverbrook in 1961 that &ldquoall the unemployables of Europe would &ldquoinvade Britain if the nation was to join the ECC.The late Sir Hugh warned the bloc would &ldquosucceed where Hitler failed.The letter was penned four years after the creation of the ECC, which was then known as the common market and 12 years before Britain joined.In 1991 the ECC was absorbed by the European Union as it surged in power and size.                Brexiteer SHUTS DOWN anti-Brexit campaigner in heated TV clashThe correspondence was unearthed today at an auction and five months before Britain will leave after 45 years of membership following the Brexit result from the June 2016 EU referendum.The three-page letter is expected to sell for a minimum of &pound1,500 with Nottingham-based International Autograph Auctions.Lord Beaverbrook was a Minister of Aircraft Production in Winston Churchill's War Cabinet at the time of the Battle of Britain in 1940.It begins with the RAF air marshall, responsible for masterminding operations in the Battle of Britain, thanking the peer for sending him a gift of cheese from the West Country.RAF pilot Sir Hugh Dowding sent a private letter to Lord Beaverbrook in 1961 (Image: )                David Davis SHUTS DOWN caller who says he's CLUELESS on business fears                Farage says Boris could cause Brexit problem if he tries to topple MayThe historic letter reads: &ldquoWhat a terrible menace this European Common Market is.&ldquoAll the unemployables of Europe will invade us &amp succeed where Hitler failed.He goes on to refer to Prime Minster Harold Macmillan's attempts to join the EEC, which would be rejected by French president Charles de Gaulle 18 months later.He wrote: &ldquoI think that even Macmillan is a bit shaken by the amount of opposition he is meeting.The correspondence was unearthed today at an auction (Image: BNPS)Lord Beaverbrook was a Minister of Aircraft Production in Winston Churchill's War Cabinet (Image: BNPS)Auctioneer Richard Davey said: &ldquoThis is a letter of exceptional and historic content, not least for the similarities Dowding writes of between Hitler and his policies during World War II and the state of the European Community in the early 1960s.&ldquoLord Dowding seldom made public comments on sensitive or controversial issues.&ldquoHowever, this is a private letter from the architect and victor of the Battle of Britain to Lord Beaverbrook.&ldquoDowding considered Beaverbrook to have been equally responsible for Britain's victory as a result of his increased production of the Spitfires and Hurricanes which ultimately overwhelmed the German Luftwaffe.The three-page letter is expected to sell for a minimum of &pound1,500 (Image: BNPS)The letter&rsquos timing is fitting as now a new French President, Emmanuel Macron, could facilitate a deal for Britain on its way out of the EU.Sir Hugh Dowding, nicknamed &ldquoStuffy by his colleagues due to his aloof character, organised the air defence systems that curbed Nazi leader Adolf Hitler&rsquos attack on the UK.

story: EU news: Weber wins support as Merkel plans EU Commission takeoverAccording to Mr MacShane, who was Labour MP for Rotherham between 1994 and 2012, Mrs Merkel would be the best choice for the title: Brexit news David Davis Europe UK EU withdrawal Theresa May Chequers latest
story: David Davis backed calls from former Foreign Minister Boris Johnson for the British Government to be tougher in the last phase of Brexit negotiations.The former Brexit Secretary urged Theresa May and her Cabinet to be more determined to ensure Britain obtains the deal it wants from the European Union.Speaking to ITV News on Monday, Mr Davis said: Boris has got a point, we have to be tough with the Europeans.We have to be more determined about it and we have to have a very clear idea of what we want.                Brexiteer SHUTS DOWN anti-Brexit campaigner in heated TV clash                Ex&ndashBrexit minister makes admission that will SHOCK Leave votersMr Davis reiterated the Chequers blueprint Mrs May presented in July did not meet the approval of Brexit voters and would not survive the scrutiny of either the British or European Parliaments at voting stage.The Tory MP, who resigned in protest of the latest Brexit white paper, suggested the Government should seek an alternative strategy to implement immediately as the country heads for the November deadline of talks with BrusselsMr Davis continued: Chequers is not what we want, it doesn&rsquot meet the promises, what we need is a free trade plus deal and that&rsquos what we should be pushing for.I think what&rsquos most likely is that the European will turn down Chequers or add so much to it, it&rsquos unacceptable. I think it&rsquos unlikely to get through Parliament. We should start thinking about our alternative strategy right now and putting it in place right now.Brexit news: David Davis told the Government to be  (Image: ITV&bull)But despite attempts from the Prime Minister to defend her white paper, EU chief negotiator Michel Barnier said the EU27 could not sign up to Chequers as it would mark the end of the single market and the European project.Mr Barnier argued that the proposed common rulebook for goods but not services would not serve the interests of the EU: Our own ecosystem has grown over decades. You cannot play with it by picking pieces.The British have a choice. They could stay in the single market, like Norway, which is also not a member of the EU - but they would then have to take over all the associated rules and contributions to European solidarity. It is your choice.Former Education Secretary Justine Greening also took aim at the Chequers deal, saying it is now more unpopular than the Poll Tax.Ms Greening said: Chequers is now dead and there's no point having a Government spending two vital months working on that when what it needs to do is start working on an alternative route for us.&nbsp

title: Brexit news UK EU Theresa May Jacob Rees Mogg Michel Barnier Brussels European Union
story: Conservative MP for North East Somerset and leading Brexit supporter Mr Rees-Mogg has praised his &ldquoencouraging meeting with Mr Barnier.The Tory MP travelled with the Common&rsquos Brexit Committee to Brussels for a private meeting on Monday with Mr Barnier, the EU's chief Brexit negotiator.Speaking in Brussels following the meeting, Mr Rees-Mogg said: &ldquoMr Barnier was, as you would expect, was extraordinarily charming and well informed.&ldquoHe and I found that we were in a considerable degree of agreement that Chequers is absolute rubbish and that we should chuck it and what we should have is a Canada-style free trade deal.                Rees-Mogg delivers hilarious quip during powerful rant at Chequers                Theresa May's rejection of second Brexit vote is 'TOTALITARIAN' &ldquoHe seemed to think that was the way forward and has published charts showing that.&ldquoSo, interestingly eurosceptics and Michel Barnier are in a greater agreement than eurosceptics and the Government or Michel Barnier and the Government, it was very encouraging.Prime Minister Theresa May defended her Chequers plan this weekend claiming that she would not accept any compromises to her blueprint &ldquothat are not in our national interest.The former Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson was critical of Mrs May&rsquos Chequers plan in his column for The Daily  claiming Chequers gives the UK &ldquotwo-thirds&nbspof diddly squat.Mr Johnson wrote: &ldquoIn adopting the Chequers proposals, we have gone into battle with the white flag fluttering over our leading tank.&ldquoIf we continue on this basis we will throw away most of the advantages of Brexit.Mrs May's spokesman&nbspresponded by&nbspsaying: &ldquoBoris Johnson resigned over Chequers.&ldquoThere's&nbspno new ideas in this article to respond to.Brexit news: Jacob Rees-Mogg claimed he and Barnier 'agreed' that Chequers was 'rubbish'  (Image: BBC&bull)&ldquoWhat we need at this time is serious leadership with a serious plan and that's exactly what the country has with this Prime Minister and this Brexit plan.On Friday the EU&rsquos Brexit negotiator Mr Barnier said the bloc wants an unprecedented partnership and an ambitious trade agreement with Britain.Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab said he is &ldquoconfident that Britain will get a deal with the EU.

title: Brexit news pound stirling dollar latest markets michel barnier
story: Peter Dragicevich, a market strategist for financial services company Suncorp, warned sterling is facing a number of &ldquoheadwinds as Brexit negotiations continue between the UK and the EU.He made the comments after chief EU negotiator Michel Barnier made an apparent U-turn on his Brexit negotation position, which saw the pound sterling drop.&nbspMr Dragicevich told CNBC: &ldquoYou look at the Brexit narrative and then it&rsquos one step forward and two steps back.&ldquoThere&rsquos still a lot of political headlines to come out and a lot of near-term risk events around that. As we&rsquove seen, the rhetoric around Brexit continues to be diluted every time there is a sign of progress.                Doom-mongers are just scaremongers, says David CollinsHe continued: &ldquoThen you add in the macro backdrop in the UK, the Bank of England is going to very slow and steady, even with a good Brexit deal.&ldquoThere&rsquos still a number of headwinds for sterling on a medium-term basis, and the Brexit narrative is still the focus for markets over the next few months.After two weeks of improvements as Brexit negotiations enter a crucial stage, pound sterling fell 0.3 per cent in early morning trading to $1.2928 against the US dollar.The currency, which had come off from a four-week peak of $1.3043 hit on Thursday, had dropped as low as $1.2892.Peter Dragicevich said that the pound stirling would be facing headwinds in the run up to Brexit  (Image: CNBC)This comes after the EU&rsquos chief Brexit negotiator Mr Barnier said he was &ldquostrongly opposed to key parts of Theresa May&rsquos proposals for a post-withdrawal trade deal, warning Britain can&rsquot &ldquocherry pick which Brussels regulations it wants to adopt on exiting the bloc.He told German newspaper Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung that the British &ldquohave a choice.Mr Barnier said: We have a coherent market for goods, services, capital and people - our own ecosystem that has grown over decades. You cannot play with it by picking pieces.There is another reason why I strongly oppose the British proposal. There are services in every product. In your mobile phone, for example, it is 20 to 40 per cent of the total value.

story: Speaking to Channel 4 News, the Brexiteer MP for North West Leicestershire said he was not opposed to a no-deal Brexit scenario, and blasted the Prime Minister's commitment to a Brexit plan which he called very poor.Mr Bridgen said: &ldquoI&rsquom not against no-deal. No deal is not as scary as people have made out. It&rsquos still WTO.&ldquoThey&rsquore rules that we helped to write, it&rsquos the way we trade with most of the world, it&rsquos the way that our trade and our exports are growing the fastest on WTO rules. It&rsquos nothing to be scared of.Veteran news anchor Jon Snow challenged Mr Bridgen's position, telling the Tory MP: &ldquoPeople did not vote to fall off a cliff.                Tory MP demands leadership challenge so UK can 'play Brexit hardball'                Brexit ultimatum: Theresa May given 10 days to SAVE leadershipMr Bridgen replied: &ldquoAnd they won&rsquot be. That rhetoric is like the millennium bug, this is all hype.&ldquoI&rsquove spoken to the ports. There is no problem with moving to WTO, except for Dover because you turn up and go and they will need to change their position.The Tory MP has previously claimed the Prime Minister's Chequers proposal would jeopardise Britons' trust in democracy and in the Conservative Party at future general elections.He told Jon Snow this evening: &ldquoThe Chequers plan is very poor.Brexit News: Andrew Bridgen has said he would accept a no deal Brexit  (Image: Channel 4)I&rsquove been very clear, we wouldn&rsquot support Chequers if the EU were paying us for it, let alone if we were spending &pound39billion of taxpayers money.Theresa May&rsquos Chequers plans are coming under increasing strain from within her own party and outside it, with European Union chief negotiator rejecting her plans as &ldquoillegal, insane and impractical.Mr Barnier ruled out any special economic relationship with the UK and warned that to do so would unravel the entire &ldquoEuropean project.The Brussels bigwig told German newspaper Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung that the British &ldquohave a choice.Mr Barnier said: &ldquoThey could stay in the single market, like Norway, which is also not a member of the EU, but they would then have to accept all the regulations and make contributions to European solidarity.But if we let the British cherrypick which of our regulations to follow, that would have serious consequence: all sorts of other third countries could insist that we offer them the same deal.On Monday, Boris Johnson blasted the Prime Minister's plans for Brexit forcing Number 10 into a public attack on the former Foreign Secretary.And former Brexit Secretary David Davis, who resigned over the Chequers Deal, described the plans as &ldquoactually almost worse than being in.

title: Brexit news Mark Carney Bank of England governor departure date extended
story: Mr Carney was originally hired for a five year term in 2013, but agreed to stay on for another year in the wake of the EU referendum.There have been reports the Treasury wants to extend his contract again to prevent a newcomer taking over the helm at such a pivotal point.Some Conservative and Labour MPs, as well as City investors, have come out to support the extension.Conservative MP George Freeman said: &ldquoWe need a Brexit that doesn&rsquot damage business confidence, investment and jobs.                IDS says Carney &lsquogot it WRONG&rsquo as he attacks &lsquopanicking&rsquo markets                Mark Carney on brink as Treasury reject Bank of England claims&ldquoMark Carney is the Alex Ferguson of the City - if he&rsquoll do it he would be a smart pick.Another Conservative MP, Ed Vaizey, said: &ldquoThe last thing we need is more upheaval next year, so Carney should be offered a contract extension if he wants&nbspit. He would help to smooth Brexit.However, staunch Brexiteer and critic of the Governor Jacob Rees-Mogg dismissed the idea of extending the contract further.He said: &ldquoCarney refused an eight-year term as Governor, accepting a shorter one, which was then extended.BANK of England Governor Mark Carney has been urged to stay in his job and oversee Brexit (Image: )Jacob Rees-Mogg has said extended the contract further would be ridiculous (Image: )&ldquoTo change it again would be ridiculous.Mr Carney has been pessimistic about Brexit in the past.Last month he said the possibility of a no-deal Brexit was &ldquouncomfortably high and &ldquohighly undesirable.In response to the reports the Treasury approached Mr Carney on staying until 2020, the department said they did not recognise the reporting, although it did indicate it had not yet found a replacement.                Tiny interest rate hike made for all the wrong reasonsMark Carney has already extended his original five-year term to six years (Image: )Downing Street said last night: &ldquoHe has said he is stepping down in June 2019.&nbsp&ldquoThe Treasury have said we&rsquoll start recruiting for a new Governor. And that is the plan.However, Theresa&rsquos May&rsquos spokesman did not entirely rule out Mr Carney changing his mind and said: &ldquoThe PM thinks the governor has done a good job.Mr Carney will be answering questions from the Treasury Select Committee on the Bank of England&rsquos inflation reports this afternoon.The Treasury has not yet appointed a new Governor (Image: )Several Labour members of the Treasury committee have stated they believe the Canadian would help UK&rsquos economy if Britain ended up with a no-deal Brexit.Labour Wes Streeting said: &ldquoGiven the Government&rsquos disastrous handling of the negotiations and increasing likelihood of a bad or no-deal, having an experienced governor at the helm would be incredibly reassuring.Some City investors have also suggested the continuity could provide stability for the nation.Anthony Gillham, head of investment at Quilter Investors, said: &ldquoCarney is a known quantity and would subsequently offer a degree of calm that could help to reinforce confidence in the margins.

title: Star has days to live
story: Who is BBC presenter Rachael Bland who announced she has days to live?Bland, who lives in Cheshire with her husband of six years and their two-year-old son Freddie, discovered in May that her cancer had become incurable.&nbspWriting about her experience last month, she revealed she had not yet asked how long she had left as she didn&rsquot want to be &ldquocounting down.&nbsp&ldquoI&rsquom not scared of dying,&nbspshe said. &ldquoI only fear for those I leave behind. I have to suppress a lot of the darkest thoughts about Freddie growing up without his mummy around.&nbspRachael discovered in May that her cancer had become incurable (Image: TWITTERRACHAELBLAND)&ldquoIf I didn&rsquot, I wouldn&rsquot be able to enjoy the precious times we have left together.&nbspThe Welsh presenter is racing to finish her memoirs to help her son navigate life without her.&nbspShe said: &ldquoAs he grows up he&rsquoll get all the stories about me from my husband Steve.&nbsp&ldquoBut he doesn&rsquot remember them all in the way that I remember them.&nbspI hope he can read my personality off the page and hear my voice through it.&nbspShe has also been documenting her experiences on her blog, Big C Little Me, and in a podcast series &ndash You, Me and the Big C.&nbspFollowing Bland&rsquos announcement, friends and colleagues offered their support on Twitter.&nbsp&nbspRachael Bland and her mum (Image: NA)BBC Breakfast presenter Steph McGovern said: &ldquoI am so gutted for you and your family. The podcast has clearly helped so many people and you did it with such style, humour and bloody brilliance.&nbsp&ldquoThank you for everything you have done.&nbspMatch of the Day 2 presenter Mark Chapman said: &ldquoOh Rachael. I am so very sorry.&nbsp&ldquoWhat you have done has been amazing and helped so many. Sending so much love to you.

title: Nana splits 84 gym star
story: The grandmother competed for Great Britain at the 1952 and 1960 Olympic Games (Image: SWNS)The grandmother competed for Great Britain at the 1952 and 1960 Olympic Games before becoming a coach.And the nimble octogenarian refuses to let old age slow her down, performing cartwheels and headstands with ease as part of her training routine.Marjorie is now hoping she can encourage other elderly people to remain fit and active.The mother of two still trains three times a week in a gym, regularly starting her workouts at 6am.                Former Olympian Jacquie Beltrao reveals her style secrets                Olympian Nile Wilson reveals a challenge &ndash 21 days to get beach readyShe first took up gymnastics at the relatively late age of 10 but, just eight years later, was selected for the British squad.Marjorie, from Bradford, West Yorks, said: &ldquoBeing selected to represent my country was truly exhilarating.&ldquoIt was such an honour and those memories of the opening ceremony will last a lifetime.&ldquoEveryone is always blown away when I tell them my story so that&rsquos always nice to share.After retiring from active competition Marjorie became a trainer, coaching gymnastics for 25 years. Speaking of her impressive flexibility and strength, the former Olympian said: &ldquoYou need to keep moving. &ldquoIt&rsquos so important when you get older to maintain that independence and mobility. As they say, use it or you lose it.&ldquoPeople in the gym always say, &lsquoYou inspire me so much&rsquo, which puts a huge smile on my face and keeps me motivated.&ldquoIt definitely helps keep me young.Proving she still has a taste for competition, Marjorie recently bagged the top prize in a nationwide Inspirational Generation competition.Marjorie has maintained her Olympian training standards (Image: SWNS)The contest was set up by retirement home builder McCarthy &amp Stone to celebrate the inspiring feats of older people.Marjorie, who lives with her partner Geoffrey, received &pound2,000 for winning, plus &pound200 to donate to a charity of her choice.She added: &ldquoI didn&rsquot think I&rsquod win, so I was absolutely overwhelmed to get that call. I had to take a minute to come to terms with it all.&ldquoIt was a true honour.

title: Brexit news Jacob Rees Mogg Michel Barnier BBC Newsnight Chequers plan
story: Appearing on BBC Newsnight, Mr Rees-Mogg told presenter Evan Davis he and the EU&rsquos chief negotiator have only met once and therefore are not the greatest buddies at this stage.However, the leading Brexiteer complimented Mr Barnier for his enormous charisma and noted he is opposed to Chequers as much as he is.He told Evan Davis: I was at the meeting with Michel Barnier today, he is clear that Chequers doesn't work.The two bits that don&rsquot work are the customs arrangement and the common rule book.                Rees-Mogg: It's a vanity project for Cameron                Rees-Mogg delivers hilarious quip during powerful rant at ChequersHe said these two were incompatible.The Tory MP's praise for the EU's chief negotiator was not the first positive comment of the week.As soon as he emerged from the commission&rsquos headquarters after their meeting in Brussels on Monday, Mr Rees-Mogg highlighted again how extraordinarily charming Mr Barnier was.He said: &ldquoHe and I found considerable agreement that Chequers is complete rubbish and we should chuck it and have a Canada-style free trade deal.Jacob Rees-Mogg has praised Michel Barnier for his charm and sophistication  (Image: BBCGetty)Rees-Mogg and Barnier bonded over their shared distaste for Theresa May&rsquos Chequers plan (Image: Getty)&ldquoInterestingly, Eurosceptics and Michel Barnier are in greater agreement than Eurosceptics and the Government or Michel Barnier and the government.It is very encouragingIt is not entirely clear what Michel Barnier's position is as only a month ago the EU's chief negotiator blamed Jacob Rees-Mogg for increasing the risk of a no deal Brexit by challenging Theresa May as she attempted to guide through key legislation for Britain&rsquos EU orce.Mr Barnier said in July: &ldquoIf we now start to see amendments blocking any possible solution, the United Kingdom Government risk getting closer to a no deal.                'EU must be sensible' Germany urges Brussels to make Brexit COMPROMISE                Brexit deal row means HAVOC for markets warns expert as pound PLUMMETSLast month Barnier blamed Jacob Rees-Mogg for increasing the risk of a no deal Brexit (Image: Getty)He added: &ldquoThe amendments adopted last night certainly do not simplify matters&mdashon the single VAT system, for example.However, in his latest and most vocal criticism of UK&rsquos negotiating stance, the French man said the British were trying to cherry pick from EU regulations.He said: &ldquoIf we let the British pick the cherries out of our rules, that would have serious consequences.&ldquoThat would be the end of the single market and the European project.

I don&rsquot see a complete fall out.Brexit news: Professor says Britain will not be  (Image: &bullCNBC)&ldquoThat&rsquos not in the interests of the EU.Theresa May&rsquos Chequers plans is coming under increasing strain from within her own party and outside it, with European Union chief negotiator rejecting her plans as &ldquoillegal, insane and impractical.The EU's chief Brexit negotiator Michel Barnier ruled out any special economic relationship with the UK and warned that to do so would unravel the entire &ldquoEuropean project.Mr Barnier told German newspaper Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung that the British &ldquohave a choice.Mr Barnier said: &ldquoThey could stay in the single market, like Norway, which is also not a member of the EU, but they would then have to accept all the regulations and make contributions to European solidarity.But if we let the British cherrypick which of our regulations to follow, that would have serious consequence: all sorts of other third countries could insist that we offer them the same deal.On Monday, Boris Johnson blasted the Prime Minister's plans for Brexit forcing Number 10 into a public attack on the former Foreign Secretary.Mr Johnson said the Chequers proposal offers Britain &ldquotwo thirds of diddly squat and the &ldquoinevitable outcome if negotiations continue as they are will be a &ldquovictory for the EU. story: SNP politician James Dornan warned the British Government's behaviour toward Scotland during the Brexit negotiations is likely to fire up support for independence in Scotland.Mr Dornand claimed the arrogance of the Government had highlighted how Scottish voices are allegedly ignored in Westminister and hinted the growing dissent could provide Nicola Sturgeon with a motive to call for a new independence referendum.&nbspSpeaking to RT UK, Mr Dornan said: The people of Scotland voted to Remain and we always have to remember that at the forefront of our mind. The people of Scotland voted to remain in the European Union and I think that our views have been discarded by Westminster.The arrogance that&rsquos coming out of the Westminster Government and the ministers is quite shocking. The people of Scotland are seeing that it&rsquos not just about Europe, it&rsquos the fact that Scotland&rsquos voice is not being heard on issues of importance.                Sturgeon says Scotland to GO after Brexit as UK too Brexit 'obsessed'A shocking Deltapoll&nbspsurvey conducted on behalf of campaign&nbspgroup Our Future Our Choice found 47 percent of 1,022 Scots polled would back independence in the event of a hard Brexit. Opponents polled at 43 percent&nbspwhile 10 percent remained undecided.&nbspIn the 2014 Scottish Independence referendum, the &lsquono&rsquo side won with 2,001,926 - or 53 percent - voting against Scotland becoming separate to the UK, while 1,617,989 - 44 percent - voted for independence. The turnout was 84.6 percent.Mr Dornan continued: The more that people realise that those that have driven us here have driven us through a mix of self-interest and a xenophobia that is frightening from senior politicians and the supporters then I think the people of Scotland will quite clearly see those figures of 47 percent growth to over 50 percent.That&rsquos not including the don&rsquot knows who I would expect to start come to us as well.Brexit news: A new poll growing support for Scottish independence in the event of hard Brexit  (Image: RT UK&bull)Scottish MEP Catherine Stihler said the results showed that Brexit posed a clear and present danger to the future of the United Kingdom.The shocking poll also found that in the event of a hard Brexit a majority of Northern Irish citizens would vote to scrap the border with the Irish Republic.The survey found 52 percent would support Irish reunification after Brexit by scrapping the border which has plagued trade deal negotiations with Brussels since the June 2016 referendum.Up to 1,199 Northern Ireland citizens took part in the ballot which was conducted between August 27 and 30 and featured the question &lsquoImagine now that the UK decided to leave the EU. Under these circumstances how would you vote in a referendum on the constitutional arrangements of the island of Ireland?&rsquoMore than half said they would vote for a united Ireland compared to 39 percent who said they would rather Northern Ireland remain part of the UK.

story: Lidl in Belgium has blocked emails between 6pm and 7am (Image: getty)The decision was taken by Lidl management in Belgium, who have blocked all internal email traffic between 6pm in the evening and 7am the following day.&nbspUnfortunately their colleagues in the UK have not been granted the same right to disconnect when they clock off.&nbspA spokesman for Lidl UK said that they &ldquooperate separately from Lidl Belgium.A Lidl Belgium spokesman said that the company was taking the measure as some employees felt obliged to be reachable around the clock so they could give an instant reply if needed. title: UK Weather forecast this week Met Office forecast news BBC Weather Britain weather latest
story: UK weather is on track to take a nosee as forecasters said temperatures could drop to -2C as early as September 4.Met Office meteorologist Aidan McGivern warned that parts of Scotland and Northern Ireland could see the first appearances of a biting cold weather system on Tuesday.&nbspThe Met Office forecaster said: East Anglia and the southeast, clear skies overnight, temperatures falling away, maybe even a few fog patches forming from the wash down to London.For Scotland and Northern Ireland, with much cooler air and lengthy clear spells, temperatures will fall away and in sheltered spots -1C or even -2C.                BBC Weather forecast: Temperature PLUMMETS as summer scorcher ENDS                UK weather forecast: Shock chart shows FROST will strike Britain The bone-chilling weather at the start of the day will give way to widespread fine weather with relatively low chances of rain in the north of the country while thermometers are expected to remain steady in the lower 20s.Mr McGivern continued: Chilly start for Scotland and Northern Ireland but that&rsquos where we&rsquoll see a lot of fine weather as we begin Tuesday.Sunny spells and a brighter day to come for West England into Wales, Cornwall as well, sunny skies breaking out. We&rsquove still got this legacy of cloud across central areas, notice how it&rsquos sinking slowly southeastwards.The rain will tend to peter out so many places dry and again we keep some warm air ahead of that. Sunny spells and temperatures of 23C or 24C.UK Weather forecast: Thermometers will drop to -2C on Tuesday morning (Image: WXCHARTS&bullMET OFFICE)BBC Weather forecaster Ben Rich warned the cold weather system will remain in place throughout Tuesday preventing rainfalls but conditions will begin to change starting on Wednesday.Mr Rich said: Our frontal system just refuses to get out of the way. It&rsquos still going to be sitting around on Tuesday, not much more than a stripe of cloud at this stage.There will be some spells of sunshine. Even in the southeast, those temperatures are coming down, 16C to 21C at best.He added: That cooler feel is one of the features of the forecast this week. Often dry at first but a bit of change, a chance of some rain later in the week.The cold snap comes as the Met Office confirmed 2018 marked the hottest summer ever on record for England. Highs for the summer tied with the scorching temperatures of the 2006, 2003 and 1976 heatwaves.&nbsp

story: Mr Abe addressed 180 Self-Defence Force (SDF) officers and explained the security threat has grown at a much faster pace in recent years and implied Japan must make room for the building up of military forces.These comments come just days after Japan and the US held military drills in the contested South China Sea, in a move that is likely to alienate the Chinese government as tensions between the countries escalate.Mr Abe said: &ldquoArranging an environment where all SDF personnel can fulfil their duties with strong pride is the responsibility of politicians living in the present.&ldquoI am determined to fully carry out my duty.                Armada of US warships inches through South China Sea with Japan The speech was delivered just three weeks to go before the leadership election of the ruling party, the Liberal Democrat Party, which Mr Abe is expected to win.If the predictions come to fruition, Mr Abe will soon be Japan&rsquos longest serving Prime Minister.Tensions bubbling up between Japan and China, especially regarding islands in the South China Sea which they both lay claim to, and fears about North Korea&rsquos nuclear capability may push the Japanese government to amend its pacifist constitution that has been in place since 1947.Although Mr Abe&rsquos speech yesterday did not directly mention amending the constitution, he has said repeatedly in the last year that he wants to add an explicit reference to the SDF in the constitution's war-renouncing Article 9.PACIFISM could be on the way out in Japan after 70 years (Image: )Japan marked the end of WW2 in August (Image: )If this change was made, it would not be possible for anyone to declare Japan&rsquos military &ldquounconstitutional.Currently, there is significant debate on the legitimacy of the SDF, which Mr Abe describes as &ldquothoughtless criticism.Last month, the Japanese Prime Minister asserted his government should submit constitutional revisions to an extraordinary Diet session expected to take place in the autumn - Diet being Japan&rsquos legislature.Yesterday&rsquos speech also emphasised the need to review the country&rsquos defence build-up guidelines drawn up five years ago, which could allow for the further building up of arms. title: EU news juncker eu ombudsman martin selmayr
story: Mr Juncker sparked outrage when he abruptly installed Martin Selmayr as Secretary-General of the European Commission - effectively the head of the EU civil service - in February.And now European Ombudsman Emily O'Reilly has ruled against him for the inappropriate blurring of the line between administrative independence and political closeness over the appointment.She found Mr Juncker guilty of four instances of maladministration by not following the rules either in letter or in sprit and said his failiure to do so had undermined public trust.Ms O&rsquoReilly examined the secrecy surrounding the impending retirement of the outgoing secretary-general, an artificial urgency to fill the post that went unchallenged by Juncker's 27 fellow commissioners from member states and Mr Selmayr's appointment as a deputy to his predecessor just minutes before being promoted to the top job.                Merkel backs German ally who mocked Brexit to replace Juncker                Angela Merkel should be given TOP JOB at EU - insists ex-Labour MPShe criticised the Commission for defensive, evasive and at times combative responses to media questions on the arcane manoeuvres around the publication of vacancies and selection of candidates which preceded an appointment that Juncker and his fellow commissioners were always free to make.And she also blasted fellow commissioners for failing to question why Mr Juncker was rushing through a new job for his Chief of Staff.Mr Selmayr, whose combative style has won the German both admirers and many enemies in Brussels, will keep his job despite the findings.But the Ombudsman&rsquos report does little to enhance the EU executive's reputation after the European Parliament accused Mr Juncker of a coup-like action just as backers of stronger EU institutions gear up to fight eurosceptics in elections next May.Jean-Claude Juncker (Image: REUTERS)A statement from the Ombudsman's office said: Our inquiry shows the precise steps the Commission took in order to make the appointment process appear normal.The Commission created an artificial sense of urgency to fill the post of Secretary-General in order to justify not publishing a vacancy notice.It also organised a Deputy Secretary-General selection procedure, not to fill that role, but rather to make Mr Selmayr Secretary-General in a rapid two-step appointment.All of this risked jeopardising the hard-won record of high EU administrative standards and consequently, the public trust.                Eurocrat gloats at our defeat                Selmayr summons EU's UK staff back to Brussels to learn their futureMr Juncker, a former premier of Luxembourg, retires late next year and government leaders and Parliament will oversee the appointment of a new Commission for the next five-year mandate.As a civil servant, Mr Selmayr would be expected to retain his role running the 30,000-strong administration in Brussels during a transition but could be replaced under Mr Juncker's successor.

title: autumn start summer end 2018 equinox
story: Those of us who are looking forward to cooler times might wonder when the seasons officially change... Heres all you need to know...There are two different dates that mark the end of summer and the beginning of autumn.These depend if you are referring to astronomical autumn or the meteorological autumn.For meteorologists, summer comes to an end on August 31 and autumn begins on September 1, running until Thursday, November 30.But astronomers say summer ends on September 22 in the northern hemisphere and autumn begins on Friday, September 23.Both astronomers and meteorologists use different ways in deciding when the seasons change.For meteorologists, they use the Gregorian calendar to split the year into four equal periods to help them with weather forecasting.This means they define autumn as taking place in September, October and November - so for them, autumn begins on September 1 and runs until November 30.But astronomers base their seasons on celestial events, and for autumn, the date is decided when the hours of daylight and darkness are roughly the same.This usually occurs around September 21-23 in the northern hemisphere, and astronomers believe the first day of autumn lies within this region.There is also a third way of determining when autumn starts that is used by people who study phenology - plant and animal life cycles.They look to changes in the natural world to determine seasons changing such as leaves changing colours and autumn fruits ripening.But this relies more on weather, so the date for this can be open and change vastly each year.This year the autumn equinox in the northern hemisphere takes place on September 23 - the same day as the beginning of astronomical autumn.The autumn equinox marks the day when the northern hemisphere slightly tilts away from the sun, meaning days become shorter and the temperature begins to cool.This carries on until the winter solstice until the northern hemisphere begins to tip back towards the sun on its axis.The end of autumn officially falls on December 21.

title: michael gove jeremy corbyn frank field
story: In the Eighties Liverpool was the battleground for the soul of the Labour Party. Far left Trotskyite infiltrators â€” operating under the banner of the Militant Tendency â€” took over the city council.Under the leadership of the charismatic but confrontational Derek Hatton they were set on purging traditional Labour voices and creating Moscow on the Mersey.They ramped up tension between the city and central Government by playing politics with council jobs.Their antics provoked then Labour leader Neil Kinnock into giving one of his most famous speeches when he condemned the â€œgrotesque chaosâ€ of a Labour Council sending redundancy notices to its own workers by taxi. Eventually, the moderates won, Militant was defeated and the city was saved.But now, fast forward 33 years and another titanic struggle for the future of Labour is being played out in Merseyside.Veteran Labour MP Frank Field who was the target of Militant in the Eighties, has sensationally been thrown out of the party heâ€™s served all his life after resigning the whip in protest at the rise of the new extremists.But this time itâ€™s not just Liverpool thatâ€™s being taken over by the hard Left but the Labour Party itself.And instead of Labourâ€™s leader mounting a fightback for moderation, as Neil Kinnock did, the leadership of Jeremy Corbyn is the heart of the problem.Corbyn will be in Liverpool later this month for Labourâ€™s own party conference â€” where the fate of the party may be decided.Will it cement victory for the new militants, now calling themselves Momentum, or be the moment that we get, in every sense, the opposition we need?Iâ€™ve known Frank for many years and heâ€™s Labour to the core.Heâ€™s dedicated his life to fighting poverty. He has been a tough critic of my party and speaks with the moral authority of someone whose whole life has been given to serving the poorest.He pursued Philip Green over the collapse of BHS and got millions back for the companyâ€™s pensioners.But because Frank is an authentic spokesman for working people, including on issues like Brexit, heâ€™s been targeted by the new militants who want everyone to follow Comrade Corbynâ€™s rigid party line.Frank is also heir to the Old Labour tradition of fighting racism and intolerance wherever it comes from. A war baby, he cherishes the role Labour played in defeating fascism. So when he takes such a stand against the party he loves, and does so citing the leaderâ€™s own complicity in anti-Semitism, then this is an alarm bell no-one can ignore.Other Merseyside MPs including Luciana Berger and Louise Ellman have also spoken out against rising anti-Semitism and intolerance within Labour ranks and the abuse they have received is truly shocking.The question now must be, will others follow Frank?With not just local parties, but the leadership itself, implacably in the grip of the hard Left, can moderates stay, and thus lend cover and credibility to the current leader?Labour was the party, when Frank was a boy, which helped create the state of Israel as a homeland for the Jewish people, which helped build Nato as a bulwark of Western values and which put the interests of working people first.Now that Labourâ€™s leadership is criticised by our own Chief Rabbi for its attitude to Israel and the Jewish community, now that Labour has a leader who doesnâ€™t believe in Nato and a strong defence, now that Labour is more interested in single-issue protest than building a better future for workers, can the majority of Labourâ€™s MPs, who are decent, hard-working and moderate, really stay?Frank is right to shine a light on the issue of anti-Semitism. And not just because it is truly horrendous that, after the horrors unleashed in the 20th Century, this intolerance should return.But also because attitudes towards the Jewish community are the best indicator of how free and progressive a country is.Throughout history, the countries where Jewish people have felt safest, like the Netherlands and the UK, have been among the worldâ€™s freest.Countries where Jewish people have faced growing prejudice, like Germany and Russia during the last century, have been countries slipping into darkness.And as the Chief Rabbi has reminded us, what starts with prejudice against Jewish people spreads to taint society more widely.The Jewish community is the canary in the coal mine.And if our democracy is to stay strong then we need to have political parties that are broad-based social movements and not increasingly ideological sects.I am a Tory but I grew up to admire and respect the patriotic Labour tradition of people like Clement Attlee, Ernie Bevin, Jim Callaghan, Peter Shore, Barbara Castle and Frank Field.I wish him well and hope that his bravery will prove the wake-up call his party and the country needs to ensure thereâ€™s a sensible party of the centre left once more.NO more heroes any more, the Stranglers sang. Well, they reckoned without Lewis Pugh, a man whose grit, endurance, idealism and dedication make him the very model of a modern hero.Lewis is the endurance swimmer who powered his way into the record books this week by covering the length of the English Channel â€“ from Landâ€™s End to Dover â€“ in 50 days.He covered the 330 miles â€“ past the Eddystone Lighthouse, the Isle of Wight and Dungeness Power station â€“ in just Speedos, cap and goggles.In stormy waters, sometimes swimming in the dead of night, through rain and high winds, with shoulder injuries, jellyfish stings and treacherous currents to slow him down, Lewis triumphed in a trial of character and cojones, which takes the breath away.But what drove Lewis on was not a desire to etch his name in the record books.It was a swelling passion for our seas, the wildlife in them and the future of our planet.In our own waters, and across the globe, the seas have suffered as a result of past exploitation, the growing danger from climate change, acidification and the rising tide of plastic waste.We have an opportunity to change that now.Leaving the EUâ€™s Common Fisheries Policy means we can have a more sustainable approach to managing the fish in our seas.And reducing our reliance on single-use plastics, as well as improving recycling, can stem the flow of waste into our seas.But there is still more to do and making sure that more of the Earthâ€™s surface is protected from exploitation is critical.Lewis records that during the length of his swim he encountered jellyfish in abundance, happy to bask in our warming waters, but far fewer fish, dolphins and other marine wildlife than he would have expected.As another modern hero, Sir David Attenborough, has reminded us, our Blue Planet is a precious but fragile place and we all have a responsibility to think about our impact on our seas.But the good news is that more and more people in Britain are cutting down on plastic, recycling more and helping nature recover, which is heroic in itself.The tech giant is planning to co-operate with China to censor material online.But it wonâ€™t respond to calls from the UK, US and others to co-operate in removing horrific images of abuse.The companyâ€™s motto used to be â€œDonâ€™t be evilâ€ but that was dropped earlier this year. Now we know why.Iâ€™M not surprised Prince Harry burst into song â€“ albeit briefly â€“ when he and wife Meghan met the cast of hit musical Hamilton.The hip-hop lyrics are infectiously catchy, so much so the Gove family often sing along to them in the car.And a musical about breaking free from an overbearing and distant overlord who doesnâ€™t govern in your interests does have a special resonance for us.Happily, she accepted and will presumably now promise to forsake all udders.SAD to see the lovely Kirsty Young having to take a break from Desert Island Discs to battle fibromyalgia.This terrible condition â€“ marked by chronic pain and extreme fatigue â€“ has no ready cure.It can strike any of us down, casting a shadow over even the simplest pleasures.I hope Kirsty recovers soon Â­â€“ and I also hope that the light shone on this illness hastens progress towards a cure.Almost everything you need for a healthy, balanced diet can be sourced from British farms and fishermen.And you know it will have been caught or grown in a way that respects the environment.Instead of our diet going south, why not save on the food miles and help the planet by buying British?THE return of Strictly to our screens this autumn divides the Gove household. But not in the way you might think.My wife canâ€™t stand the show and my daughter cringes at it â€“ but my son and I are hooked.Weâ€™ve cheered on Ed Ballsâ€™ Gangnam Style and rooted for Susan Calman last year.This year I think Casualty actor Charles Venn and Paralympian Lauren Steadman could become popular favourites.But no, I wonâ€™t be harbouring dreams of joining in. There is no politician worse at dancing than me.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: brexit trading superpower small business liam fox
story: They want to buy British products, use British services, learn English. They trust our laws and our financial services, they admire our Armed Forces and they envy our universities.Actually, thatâ€™s not quite true: everywhere I go in the world, except right here in the UK.There are some who canâ€™t or wonâ€™t see the natural advantages we have and the opportunities that exist for us. I get frustrated when some people purposefully choose to ignore good news such as last week when China opened up their market to UK dairy products.Britain can and should be confident and the world needs a confident Britain.A confident Britain can bang the drum for free trade across the world, as more and more countries look to pull up the drawbridge and turn away from the huge benefits that we have seen in poverty alleviation.A confident Britain can work with African countries to tackle extremism and instability which threatens millions of people across the world, including right here in the UK, as the Prime Minister promised to do this week.A confident Britain with an independent seat at the World Trade Organisation can be a leading voice for free trade and prosperity.A confident Britain is good for the world, and itâ€™s good for us at home too.Â Why?Because free trade means we can sell more world-class British goods and services across the globe. That means safeguarding and creating jobs as well generating revenues for the Treasury to spend on our vital public services.Thatâ€™s why I launched the Export Strategy last month: to turn the UK into a 21st Century exporting superpower.We need to work together to Â­create a more confident Britain that can export to the world.To do that, we need to support business the length and breadth of the whole UK.Over 99 per cent of our businesses are small or medium-sized, and 96 per cent are micro-sized, employing fewer than nine people.That means many thousands of Sun on Sunday readers either own one or work for one.You are the lifeblood of our economy â€” itâ€™s your entrepreneurship, risk-taking and innovation that drives the entire economy.Itâ€™s your wealth creation that provides the income we all depend on for our public services, from funding our NHS to paying our brave Armed Forces.It also means that you might not be exporting â€” yet â€” because more than 90 per cent of companies arenâ€™t currently seizing the opportunities of exporting.Thatâ€™s where we can help.Government doesnâ€™t manufacture products and doesnâ€™t provide services for exporting.But we can help create the right conditions by intervening where only government can.We have created a network of Her Majestyâ€™s Trade Commissioners to lead the Governmentâ€™s trade and investment promotion and policy in high-growth regions across the world.And I as International Trade Secretary can step in and speak to foreign ministers about overcoming a trade barrier â€” as I did last week, when I signed a deal in Beijing to enable the UK to export seed potatoes to China or help a UK company close a deal in an overseas market or seal a partnership with a foreign company.And to support British businesses â€” whether they produce farm products, or manufacture playgrounds, or provide legal services â€” we are also creating a network of Export Champions, people who run businesses that successfully export, to guide their peers and share their expertise.As Iâ€™ve often said before, in the next ten to 15 years, around 90 per cent of global economic growth is expected to be outside the EU.I truly believe that Brexit is an Â­opportunity.The positive response and engagement weâ€™ve seen from the EU negotiators to the Chequers proposals makes me believe that a good deal is now more likely.At Chequers the Government agreed its proposal for an economic partnership with the EU after the UK leaves on March 29, 2019.It confirmed that the UK will leave the Single Market and the Customs Union and will seize new opportunities from trading with the rest of the world.Thatâ€™s why the Prime Minister visited Africa, one of the fastest-growing regions in the world, this week.Itâ€™s why I visited China last week, and am visiting India later in the autumn, to ensure Britain can make the most of their breakneck growth.Booming countries across the globe are confident in Britain.Theyâ€™re confident in our crucial role in supporting world prosperity, world security and world growth.If they have faith in us, we need to have more faith. Because a more confident Britain is a better Britain for the world.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: frank fields big mistake backing corbyn
story: His only mistake â€” which he wears like a hair shirt â€” was to back Jeremy Corbyn as Â­Labour leader, hoping he and his Momentum thugs would be trashed in the process.The man who fought the loony Left in his own Merseyside constituency should have known better. He knows now.Last week, Field quit the Labour Party whip amid a barrage of â€œintolerance, nastiness and intimidationâ€ from Corbyn outriders over his stand against anti-Semitism.Along with other moderate Labour MPs, he was battered by Twitter storms using the vilest language to wish him dead.Field bluntly accuses Jeremy Corbyn of racism and hints he is ready to force a by-election if kicked out of the Labour Party. Others facing deselection may follow suit.Leadership critics have endured relentless bullying and abuse, a trademark of the brutal machine which swept Jezza to power and intends to keep him there. As Frank Field himself now admits, Corbyn is going nowhere.The party might split but the ageing hippy â€œwill lead Labour into the next electionâ€. Corbynâ€™s sullen anti-Semitism triggered this revolt, but it is only a symptom of the sinister nature of hard-Left politics which brooks no criticism.Labour really is the Nasty Party. Jezzaâ€™s pro-Russian, anti-capitalist malcontents loathe everything the UK and other Western democracies stand for.They support some of the worldâ€™s most brutal tyrannies and catastrophic economies while railing against free speech and Press freedom.Corbyn sees no evil in these repressive forces and this week shelved an invitation from MI5 chiefs to show him the secret intelligence. On such evidence alone, it is fair to say Corbyn as PM would permanently damage this country, its freedoms and its prosperity.We knew all this when Ed Miliband threw open the partyâ€™s leadership to anyone with three quid to buy a vote. Thanks to his stunning act of stupidity, the â€œbroad churchâ€ Labour Party of Clem Attlee, Hugh Gaitskell, John Smith and Tony Blair is history.It lives on in name only, an empty husk colonised by Momentum parasites who once fought the party they now own. Corbyn didnâ€™t even want the job, telling supporters: â€œYouâ€™d better make f***ing sure I donâ€™t win.â€When he surprised himself by storming to victory in 2015, shell-shocked Blairite MPs assumed they could get rid of him if he stepped too far out of line.They tried that in 2016 â€” turning Jezza into the unassailable champion of the loony Left and handing over the keys to the asylum. Theresa May bolted him in place with her botched General Election. No wonder the Glastonbury millennials cooed: â€œOh, Jeremy Corbyn.â€Have we learned from Frank Fieldâ€™s mistake? Or do we believe, as he did, voters will never be silly enough to give Corbyn the keys to power? Well, look at the polls. They show nobody much rates Jezza, but Labour remains neck and neck with the Tories.Theresa May has yet to navigate her way to a tricky Brexit deal with Brussels â€” or to a no-deal rejected by Commons Remainers. She has rightly turned her face against a second referendum, a democratic abomination.But who knows who will be leader by then? Boris Johnson is circling, helped by a growing team of sponsors and supporters. Mrs May would do anything to stop BoJo. She is even seeking official advice on another snap election gamble. Good luck with that, Theresa. But Remainers should be careful what they wish for.Corbyn, a fervent fan of arch-Eurosceptic Tony Benn, loathes the EU as much as the angry Labour supporters who voted Leave. But he would conveniently bury that hatred for the time being if it meant riding a Remainer wave into Downing Street.Pro-Brussels campaigner Keir Starmer would emerge, not for the first time, as a â€œuseful idiotâ€.The Purge will have just begun.At a media event before his referendum, the ex-oil analyst confidently bet the price would not crash below 50 a barrel. It did.Â He sent me my winnings but they apparently went astray.So he offered double-or-quits. The price stayed below 50 for yet another year â€“ and is still only a bit higher today. My winnings, Â£60 in todayâ€™s money, allegedly went to a charity. I never saw any evidence of that either.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: national lottery income for life prize
story: Operator Camelot today announced the new annuity game jackpot thatÂ could set a player up with a four-figure income every month for 25 years.Along with the new prize, another feature to be introduced from November will seeÂ anyone matching five balls plus the bonus ball winning a fixed Â£1million.A statement from the company said: Were still in the process of getting agreement from our regulator, but are currently finalising details for a brand new annuity game â€“ something very different to the big jackpot draws.The game will give winners a regular set amount of money for a certain number of years.It isnt due to launch until next year, so we dont yet have any exact information on the prizes or the cost of play.Well provide an update as soon as possible.The changes were in response to an in-depth review launched last year after sales dropped 8.8 per cent in 2016/17 compared to the previous year.Camelot chief executive Nigel Railton said: It was clear from the review that we needed to create a more appealing and balanced range of games that offers something for everyone.The review found that when Lotto changed in 2015 so that gamblers picked six numbers from 59, rather than 49, the game resembled its high-stakes sibling EuroMillions too closely because it became harder to win.1.Â Colin and Chris Weir won Â£161million on the EuroMillions in 2011.They splashed out on a stunning mansion and, included in their first purchases were a checked sports jacket, a computer and a tractor.The Scottish couple initially boughtÂ Knock House near Largs but last year they sold their mansion in favour of an even bigger pad in Troon.Last summer he went back to work after he claimed he was getting bored at his Â£6 million country mansion.In February 2017 the wealthyÂ winners younger girlfriend left him and his home wasÂ raided in a Â£100,000 burglary, all in the space of a few weeks.3. The Davies family won Â£61 million on the EuroMillions in 2016.The Welsh family said they were the luckiest people on the planet after scooping an enormous amount of cash.The jackpot will only be allowed to rollover five times in the future, compared to 10 currently.The money will roll down to the fixed categories on the sixth draw, boosting the coffers.Five balls will win at least Â£1,750 and four Â£140, both increases from their current estimated values, and three balls will net Â£30, up from Â£25 now.Wednesdays base jackpot will increase from an estimated Â£1.8million to Â£2million, and Saturdays from Â£3.1million to Â£3.8million.The maximum amount on a rollover will decrease, however, from Â£22million currently to an estimated Â£11million on a Wednesday and Â£12million on a Saturday.

title: matthew wright talkradio weekday afternoon show
story: After 18 yearsÂ fronting The Wright Stuff, the chat show veteran will hit the airwaves with his new show next Monday.The announcement comes just hours after it was revealed Chris EvansÂ has signed to Virgin, which like talkRADIO is owned by Wireless, part of News UK, which publishes The Sun.Airing Monday to Friday, between 1pm and 4pm, The Matthew Wright Show will focus on current affairs in the UK and around the world.Covering politics, arts, breaking news and everything in between, the programme willÂ feature a series of regular guests, including long-time collaborator and TV critic Kevin Oâ€™Sullivan, to review and dissect the news of the day.Announcing the news, the 53-year-old said: â€œIâ€™m absolutely thrilled to be joining talkRADIO at this fascinating time in history when thereâ€™s so much to discuss and debate.My new afternoon show will see me team up with Fleet Street legend, critic Kevin Oâ€™Sullivan - two real-life chums who donâ€™t agree on anything!â€œFree of the restrictions imposed when I was on the goggle box, Iâ€™m looking forward to full-on phone-ins and laughs a plenty, not just with talkRADIOâ€™s growing army of loyal listeners, but with an array of celebrity guests too.
